<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Mammal</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Class of animals with milk-producing glands</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Mammal_(disambiguation)" title="Mammal (disambiguation)">Mammal (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Several terms  redirect here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Mammalian_(film)" title="Mammalian (film)">Mammalian (film)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mammalia_(journal)" title="Mammalia (journal)">Mammalia (journal)</a>.</div>

<th colspan="2" style="text-align: center; background-color: rgb(235,235,210)">Living subgroups

<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="text-align: left">

<li><a href="/wiki/Placentalia" title="Placentalia">Placentalia</a></li></ul></li></ul>
</td></tr>

<p><b>Mammals</b> (from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">Latin</a> <i> <i lang="la"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mamma#Latin" title="wikt:mamma">mamma</a></i></i> 'breast')<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> are a group of <a href="/wiki/Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate">vertebrate</a> animals constituting the <a href="/wiki/Class_(biology)" title="Class (biology)">class</a> <b>Mammalia</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'m' in 'my'">m</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'m' in 'my'">m</span><span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">eɪ</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/./: syllable break">.</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span></span>/</a></span></span>), characterized by the presence of <a href="/wiki/Mammary_gland" title="Mammary gland">mammary glands</a> which in <a href="/wiki/Female#Mammalian_female" title="Female">females</a> produce <a href="/wiki/Milk" title="Milk">milk</a> for feeding (nursing) their young, a <a href="/wiki/Neocortex" title="Neocortex">neocortex</a> (a region of the brain), <a href="/wiki/Fur" title="Fur">fur</a> or <a href="/wiki/Hair" title="Hair">hair</a>, and three <a href="/wiki/Ossicles" title="Ossicles">middle ear bones</a>. These characteristics distinguish them from <a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptiles</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Bird" title="Bird">birds</a>) from which they <a href="/wiki/Genetic_divergence" title="Genetic divergence">diverged</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Carboniferous" title="Carboniferous">Carboniferous</a>, over 300 million years ago. Around 6,400 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Extant_taxon" title="Extant taxon">extant</a> <a href="/wiki/Species" title="Species">species</a> of mammals have been described divided into 29 <a href="/wiki/Order_(biology)" title="Order (biology)">orders</a>. The largest <a href="/wiki/Order_(biology)" title="Order (biology)">orders</a>, in terms of number of species, are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rodents" title="Rodents">rodents</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bats" title="Bats">bats</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eulipotyphla" title="Eulipotyphla">Eulipotyphla</a> (<a href="/wiki/Hedgehog" title="Hedgehog">hedgehogs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mole_(animal)" title="Mole (animal)">moles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shrew" title="Shrew">shrews</a>, and others). The next three are the <a href="/wiki/Primate" title="Primate">Primates</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Human" title="Human">humans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ape" title="Ape">apes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monkey" title="Monkey">monkeys</a>, and others), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Artiodactyla" title="Artiodactyla">Artiodactyla</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cetacean" title="Cetacean">cetaceans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Even-toed_ungulate" title="Even-toed ungulate">even-toed ungulates</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Carnivora" title="Carnivora">Carnivora</a> (<a href="/wiki/Cat" title="Cat">cats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dog" title="Dog">dogs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pinniped" title="Pinniped">seals</a>, and others).
</p><p>In terms of <a href="/wiki/Cladistics" title="Cladistics">cladistics</a>, which reflects evolutionary history, mammals are the only living members of the <a href="/wiki/Synapsid" title="Synapsid">Synapsida</a> (synapsids); this <a href="/wiki/Clade" title="Clade">clade</a>, together with <a href="/wiki/Sauropsida" title="Sauropsida">Sauropsida</a> (reptiles and birds), constitutes the larger <a href="/wiki/Amniote" title="Amniote">Amniota</a> clade. The early synapsids were <a href="/wiki/Sphenacodontia" title="Sphenacodontia">sphenacodonts</a>, a group that included the famous <i><a href="/wiki/Dimetrodon" title="Dimetrodon">Dimetrodon</a></i>. The synapsids split into several diverse groups of non-mammalian synapsids — traditionally and incorrectly referred to as mammal-like reptiles or by the term  pelycosaurs, and now known as stem mammals or protomammals — before giving rise to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Therapsida" title="Therapsida">therapsids</a> during the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Guadalupian" title="Guadalupian">Middle Permian</a> period. Mammals originated from <a href="/wiki/Cynodont" title="Cynodont">cynodonts</a>, an advanced group of therapsids, during the Late <a href="/wiki/Triassic" title="Triassic">Triassic</a>-Early <a href="/wiki/Jurassic" title="Jurassic">Jurassic</a>. The modern mammalian orders arose in the <a href="/wiki/Paleogene" title="Paleogene">Paleogene</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neogene" title="Neogene">Neogene</a> periods of the <a href="/wiki/Cenozoic" title="Cenozoic">Cenozoic</a> era, after the <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous%E2%80%93Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event">extinction of non-avian dinosaurs</a>, and have been the dominant<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Vagueness" title="Wikipedia:Vagueness"><span title="This information is too vague. (July 2022)">vague</span></a></i>]</sup> terrestrial animal group from 66 million years ago to the present.
</p><p>The basic body type is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quadruped" title="Quadruped">quadruped</a>, and most mammals use their four extremities for <a href="/wiki/Terrestrial_locomotion" title="Terrestrial locomotion">terrestrial locomotion</a>; but in some, the extremities are adapted for <a href="/wiki/Marine_mammal" title="Marine mammal">life at sea</a>, in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aerial_locomotion" title="Aerial locomotion">the air</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arboreal_locomotion" title="Arboreal locomotion">in trees</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fossorial" title="Fossorial">underground</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Bipedalism" title="Bipedalism">on two legs</a>. Mammals range in size from the 30–40 mm (1.2–1.6 in) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bumblebee_bat" title="Bumblebee bat">bumblebee bat</a> to the 30 m (98 ft) <a href="/wiki/Blue_whale" title="Blue whale">blue whale</a>—possibly the largest animal to have ever lived. Maximum lifespan varies from two years for the shrew to 211 years for the <a href="/wiki/Bowhead_whale" title="Bowhead whale">bowhead whale</a>. All modern mammals give birth to live young, except the five species of <a href="/wiki/Monotreme" title="Monotreme">monotremes</a>, which are egg-laying mammals. The most species-rich group of mammals, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cohort_(taxonomy)" title="Cohort (taxonomy)">cohort</a> called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Placentals" title="Placentals">placentals</a>, have a <a href="/wiki/Placenta" title="Placenta">placenta</a>, which enables the feeding of the fetus during <a href="/wiki/Gestation" title="Gestation">gestation</a>.
</p><p>Most mammals are <a href="/wiki/Animal_cognition" title="Animal cognition">intelligent</a>, with some possessing large brains, <a href="/wiki/Self-awareness" title="Self-awareness">self-awareness</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tool_use_in_animals" title="Tool use in animals">tool use</a>. Mammals can communicate and vocalize in several ways, including the production of <a href="/wiki/Ultrasound" title="Ultrasound">ultrasound</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scent-marking" title="Scent-marking">scent-marking</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alarm_signal" title="Alarm signal">alarm signals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Singing#Singing_animals" title="Singing">singing</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Animal_echolocation" title="Animal echolocation">echolocation</a>. Mammals can organize themselves into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fission-fusion_society" title="Fission-fusion society">fission-fusion societies</a>, <a href="/wiki/Harem_(zoology)" title="Harem (zoology)">harems</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hierarchy" title="Hierarchy">hierarchies</a>—but can also be solitary and <a href="/wiki/Territory_(animal)" title="Territory (animal)">territorial</a>. Most mammals are <a href="/wiki/Polygyny_in_animals" title="Polygyny in animals">polygynous</a>, but some can be <a href="/wiki/Monogamy_in_animals" title="Monogamy in animals">monogamous</a> or <a href="/wiki/Polyandry_in_nature" title="Polyandry in nature">polyandrous</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Domestication" title="Domestication">Domestication</a> of many types of mammals by humans played a major role in the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic_Revolution" title="Neolithic Revolution">Neolithic Revolution</a>, and resulted in <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">farming</a> replacing <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunting and gathering</a> as the primary source of food for humans. This led to a major restructuring of human societies from nomadic to sedentary, with more co-operation among larger and larger groups, and ultimately the development of the first <a href="/wiki/Civilization" title="Civilization">civilizations</a>. Domesticated mammals provided, and continue to provide, power for transport and agriculture, as well as food (<a href="/wiki/Meat" title="Meat">meat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dairy_product" title="Dairy product">dairy products</a>), <a href="/wiki/Fur" title="Fur">fur</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Leather" title="Leather">leather</a>. Mammals are also <a href="/wiki/Hunting" title="Hunting">hunted</a> and raced for sport, and are used as <a href="/wiki/Model_organism" title="Model organism">model organisms</a> in science. Mammals have been depicted in <a href="/wiki/Art" title="Art">art</a> since <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> times, and appear in literature, film, mythology, and religion. Decline in numbers and <a href="/wiki/Extinction" title="Extinction">extinction</a> of many mammals is primarily driven by human <a href="/wiki/Poaching" title="Poaching">poaching</a> and <a href="/wiki/Habitat_destruction" title="Habitat destruction">habitat destruction</a>, primarily <a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">deforestation</a>.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-4"><div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Classification">Classification</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mammal_classification" title="Mammal classification">Mammal classification</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_placental_mammals" title="List of placental mammals">List of placental mammals</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_monotremes_and_marsupials" title="List of monotremes and marsupials">List of monotremes and marsupials</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_mammal_genera" title="List of mammal genera">List of mammal genera</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_mammal_species" title="List of mammal species">List of mammal species</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="482" data-file-width="482" decoding="async" height="300" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg/300px-Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg/450px-Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg/600px-Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Over 70% of mammal species come from the orders <a href="/wiki/Rodent" title="Rodent">Rodentia</a>, rodents (blue); <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chiroptera" title="Chiroptera">Chiroptera</a>, bats (red); and <a href="/wiki/Soricomorpha" title="Soricomorpha">Soricomorpha</a>, shrews (yellow). <table> <tbody><tr> <td style="width:150px; vertical-align:top"> <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#63aafe; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rodentia" title="Rodentia">Rodentia</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#dd2d32; color:white;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chiroptera" title="Chiroptera">Chiroptera</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#fff58c; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Soricomorpha" title="Soricomorpha">Soricomorpha</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#4ee257; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Primates" title="Primates">Primates</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#6711ff; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Carnivora" title="Carnivora">Carnivora</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#fea746; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Artiodactyla" title="Artiodactyla">Artiodactyla</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#865357; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Diprotodontia" title="Diprotodontia">Diprotodontia</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#a2bd90; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Lagomorpha" title="Lagomorpha">Lagomorpha</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#00ccff; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Didelphimorphia" title="Didelphimorphia">Didelphimorphia</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ccffff; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Cetacea" title="Cetacea">Cetacea</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ccffcc; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Dasyuromorphia" title="Dasyuromorphia">Dasyuromorphia</a></div> </td> <td style="width:150px; vertical-align:top"> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ffff99; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Afrosoricida" title="Afrosoricida">Afrosoricida</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#99ccff; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Erinaceomorpha" title="Erinaceomorpha">Erinaceomorpha</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ff99cc; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Cingulata" title="Cingulata">Cingulata</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#cc99ff; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Peramelemorphia" title="Peramelemorphia">Peramelemorphia</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ffcc99; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scandentia" title="Scandentia">Scandentia</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#3366ff; color:white;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Perissodactyla" title="Perissodactyla">Perissodactyla</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#33cccc; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Macroscelidea" title="Macroscelidea">Macroscelidea</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#99cc00; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Pilosa" title="Pilosa">Pilosa</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ff6600; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monotremata" title="Monotremata">Monotremata</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#003366; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Sirenia" title="Sirenia">Sirenia</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#00aa55; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Proboscidea" title="Proboscidea">Proboscidea</a></div> </td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div>
<p>Mammal classification has been through several revisions since <a href="/wiki/Carl_Linnaeus" title="Carl Linnaeus">Carl Linnaeus</a> initially defined the class, and at present, no classification system is universally accepted. McKenna &amp; Bell (1997) and Wilson &amp; Reeder (2005) provide useful recent compendiums.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/George_Gaylord_Simpson" title="George Gaylord Simpson">Simpson</a> (1945)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Simpson-1945_3-0"><a href="#cite_note-Simpson-1945-3">[3]</a></sup> provides <a href="/wiki/Systematics" title="Systematics">systematics</a> of mammal origins and relationships that had been taught universally until the end of the 20th century.
However, since 1945, a large amount of new and more detailed information has gradually been found: The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fossil_record" title="Fossil record">paleontological record</a> has been recalibrated, and the intervening years have seen much debate and progress concerning the theoretical underpinnings of systematization itself, partly through the new concept of <a href="/wiki/Cladistics" title="Cladistics">cladistics</a>. Though fieldwork and lab work progressively outdated Simpson's classification, it remains the closest thing to an official classification of mammals, despite its known issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Szalay_4-0"><a href="#cite_note-Szalay-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most mammals, including the six most species-rich <a href="/wiki/Order_(biology)" title="Order (biology)">orders</a>, belong to the placental group. The three largest orders in numbers of species are <a href="/wiki/Rodent" title="Rodent">Rodentia</a>: <a href="/wiki/Mouse" title="Mouse">mice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rat" title="Rat">rats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porcupine" title="Porcupine">porcupines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beaver" title="Beaver">beavers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Capybara" title="Capybara">capybaras</a>, and other gnawing mammals; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chiroptera" title="Chiroptera">Chiroptera</a>: bats; and <a href="/wiki/Soricomorpha" title="Soricomorpha">Soricomorpha</a>: <a href="/wiki/Shrew" title="Shrew">shrews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mole_(animal)" title="Mole (animal)">moles</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Solenodon" title="Solenodon">solenodons</a>. The next three biggest orders, depending on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biological_classification" title="Biological classification">biological classification</a> scheme used, are the <a href="/wiki/Primate" title="Primate">Primates</a>: <a href="/wiki/Ape" title="Ape">apes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monkey" title="Monkey">monkeys</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lemur" title="Lemur">lemurs</a>; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cetartiodactyla" title="Cetartiodactyla">Cetartiodactyla</a>: <a href="/wiki/Whale" title="Whale">whales</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Even-toed_ungulates" title="Even-toed ungulates">even-toed ungulates</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/Carnivora" title="Carnivora">Carnivora</a> which includes <a href="/wiki/Cat" title="Cat">cats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dog" title="Dog">dogs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Weasel" title="Weasel">weasels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bear" title="Bear">bears</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pinniped" title="Pinniped">seals</a>, and allies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MSW3intro_5-0"><a href="#cite_note-MSW3intro-5">[5]</a></sup> According to <i><a href="/wiki/Mammal_Species_of_the_World" title="Mammal Species of the World">Mammal Species of the World</a></i>, 5,416 species were identified in 2006. These were grouped into 1,229 <a href="/wiki/Genus" title="Genus">genera</a>, 153 <a href="/wiki/Family_(biology)" title="Family (biology)">families</a> and 29 orders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MSW3intro_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-MSW3intro-5">[5]</a></sup> In 2008, the <a href="/wiki/International_Union_for_Conservation_of_Nature" title="International Union for Conservation of Nature">International Union for Conservation of Nature</a> (IUCN) completed a five-year Global Mammal Assessment for its <a href="/wiki/IUCN_Red_List" title="IUCN Red List">IUCN Red List</a>, which counted 5,488 species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> According to research published in the <i><a href="/wiki/Journal_of_Mammalogy" title="Journal of Mammalogy">Journal of Mammalogy</a></i> in 2018, the number of recognized mammal species is 6,495, including 96 recently extinct.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Definitions">Definitions <span class="anchor" id="variations"></span></span></h3>
<p>The word "<a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mammal" title="wikt:mammal">mammal</a>" is modern, from the scientific name <i>Mammalia</i> coined by Carl Linnaeus in 1758, derived from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">Latin</a> <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mamma#Latin" title="wikt:mamma">mamma</a></i> ("teat, pap"). In an influential 1988 paper, Timothy Rowe defined Mammalia <a href="/wiki/Phylogenetics" title="Phylogenetics">phylogenetically</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Crown_group" title="Crown group">crown group</a> of mammals, the <a href="/wiki/Clade" title="Clade">clade</a> consisting of the <a href="/wiki/Most_recent_common_ancestor" title="Most recent common ancestor">most recent common ancestor</a> of living <a href="/wiki/Monotreme" title="Monotreme">monotremes</a> (<a href="/wiki/Echidna" title="Echidna">echidnas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Platypus" title="Platypus">platypuses</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Theria" title="Theria">Therian</a> mammals (<a href="/wiki/Marsupial" title="Marsupial">marsupials</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Placental" title="Placental">placentals</a>) and all descendants of that ancestor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Since this ancestor lived in the <a href="/wiki/Jurassic" title="Jurassic">Jurassic</a> period, Rowe's definition excludes all animals from the earlier <a href="/wiki/Triassic" title="Triassic">Triassic</a>, despite the fact that Triassic fossils in the <a href="/wiki/Haramiyida" title="Haramiyida">Haramiyida</a> have been referred to the Mammalia since the mid-19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> If Mammalia is considered as the crown group, its origin can be roughly dated as the first known appearance of animals more closely related to some extant mammals than to others. <i><a href="/wiki/Ambondro_mahabo" title="Ambondro mahabo">Ambondro</a></i> is more closely related to monotremes than to therian mammals while <i><a href="/wiki/Amphilestes" title="Amphilestes">Amphilestes</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Amphitherium" title="Amphitherium">Amphitherium</a></i> are more closely related to the therians; as fossils of all three genera are dated about <span class="nourlexpansion plainlinks" style="white-space:nowrap;"><a class="external text" href="http://tools.wmflabs.org/timescale/?Ma=167">167</a> million years ago</span> in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Jurassic" title="Middle Jurassic">Middle Jurassic</a>, this is a reasonable estimate for the appearance of the crown group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>T.S. Kemp has provided a more traditional definition: "<a href="/wiki/Synapsid" title="Synapsid">Synapsids</a> that possess a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dentary" title="Dentary">dentary</a>–<a href="/wiki/Squamosal_bone" title="Squamosal bone">squamosal</a> jaw articulation and <a href="/wiki/Occlusion_(dentistry)" title="Occlusion (dentistry)">occlusion</a> between upper and lower molars with a transverse component to the movement" or, equivalently in Kemp's view, the clade originating with the last common ancestor of <i><a href="/wiki/Sinoconodon" title="Sinoconodon">Sinoconodon</a></i> and living mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> The earliest known synapsid satisfying Kemp's definitions is <i><a href="/wiki/Tikitherium" title="Tikitherium">Tikitherium</a></i>, dated <span class="nourlexpansion plainlinks" style="white-space:nowrap;"><a class="external text" href="http://tools.wmflabs.org/timescale/?Ma=225">225</a> Ma</span>, so the appearance of mammals in this broader sense can be given this <a href="/wiki/Late_Triassic" title="Late Triassic">Late Triassic</a> date.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="McKenna.2FBell_classification"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="McKenna/Bell_classification">McKenna/Bell classification</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Mammal_classification#McKenna/Bell_classification" title="Mammal classification">Mammal classification § McKenna/Bell classification</a></div>
<p>In 1997, the mammals were comprehensively revised by <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_McKenna" title="Malcolm McKenna">Malcolm C. McKenna</a> and Susan K. Bell, which has resulted in the McKenna/Bell classification. The authors worked together as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paleontologist" title="Paleontologist">paleontologists</a> at the <a href="/wiki/American_Museum_of_Natural_History" title="American Museum of Natural History">American Museum of Natural History</a>. McKenna inherited the project from Simpson and, with Bell, constructed a completely updated hierarchical system, covering living and extinct taxa, that reflects the historical genealogy of Mammalia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Szalay_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-Szalay-4">[4]</a></sup> Their 1997 book, <i>Classification of Mammals above the Species Level</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McKennaBell1997_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-McKennaBell1997-14">[14]</a></sup> is a comprehensive work on the systematics, relationships and occurrences of all mammal taxa, living and extinct, down through the rank of genus, though molecular genetic data challenge several of the groupings.
</p><p>In the following list, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Extinct" title="Extinct">extinct</a> groups are labelled with a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dagger_(typography)" title="Dagger (typography)">dagger</a> (†).
</p><p><b>Class Mammalia</b>
</p>
<ul><li><b>Subclass <a href="/wiki/Prototheria" title="Prototheria">Prototheria</a></b>: monotremes: <a href="/wiki/Echidna" title="Echidna">echidnas</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Platypus" title="Platypus">platypus</a></li>
<li><b>Subclass <a href="/wiki/Theriiformes" title="Theriiformes">Theriiformes</a></b>: live-bearing mammals and their prehistoric relatives
<ul><li>Infraclass †<a href="/wiki/Allotheria" title="Allotheria">Allotheria</a>: multituberculates</li>
<li>Infraclass †<a href="/wiki/Eutriconodonta" title="Eutriconodonta">Eutriconodonta</a>: eutriconodonts</li>
<li>Infraclass <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holotheria" title="Holotheria">Holotheria</a>: modern live-bearing mammals and their prehistoric relatives
<ul><li>Superlegion †<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kuehneotheria" title="Kuehneotheria">Kuehneotheria</a></li>
<li>Supercohort <a href="/wiki/Theria" title="Theria">Theria</a>: live-bearing mammals
<ul><li>Cohort <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marsupialia" title="Marsupialia">Marsupialia</a>: marsupials
<ul><li>Magnorder <a href="/wiki/Australidelphia" title="Australidelphia">Australidelphia</a>: Australian marsupials and the <a href="/wiki/Monito_del_monte" title="Monito del monte">monito del monte</a></li>
<li>Magnorder <a href="/wiki/Ameridelphia" title="Ameridelphia">Ameridelphia</a>: New World marsupials. Now considered paraphyletic, with <a href="/wiki/Shrew_opossum" title="Shrew opossum">shrew opossums</a> being closer to australidelphians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup></li></ul></li>
<li>Cohort <a href="/wiki/Placentalia" title="Placentalia">Placentalia</a>: placentals
<ul><li>Magnorder <a href="/wiki/Xenarthra" title="Xenarthra">Xenarthra</a>: xenarthrans</li>
<li>Magnorder <a href="/wiki/Epitheria" title="Epitheria">Epitheria</a>: epitheres
<ul><li>Superorder †<a href="/wiki/Leptictida" title="Leptictida">Leptictida</a></li>
<li>Superorder <a href="/wiki/Preptotheria" title="Preptotheria">Preptotheria</a>
<ul><li>Grandorder <a href="/wiki/Glires" title="Glires">Anagalida</a>: <a href="/wiki/Lagomorpha" title="Lagomorpha">lagomorphs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rodent" title="Rodent">rodents</a> and <a href="/wiki/Elephant_shrew" title="Elephant shrew">elephant shrews</a></li>
<li>Grandorder <a href="/wiki/Ferae" title="Ferae">Ferae</a>: <a href="/wiki/Carnivora" title="Carnivora">carnivorans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pangolin" title="Pangolin">pangolins</a>, †<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Creodont" title="Creodont">creodonts</a> and relatives</li>
<li>Grandorder <a href="/wiki/Lipotyphla" title="Lipotyphla">Lipotyphla</a>: <a href="/wiki/Insectivora" title="Insectivora">insectivorans</a></li>
<li>Grandorder <a href="/wiki/Archonta" title="Archonta">Archonta</a>: <a href="/wiki/Bat" title="Bat">bats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Primate" title="Primate">primates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colugo" title="Colugo">colugos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Treeshrew" title="Treeshrew">treeshrews</a> (now considered paraphyletic, with bats being closer to other groups)</li>
<li>Grandorder <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ungulata" title="Ungulata">Ungulata</a>: ungulates
<ul><li>Order <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tubulidentata" title="Tubulidentata">Tubulidentata</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Incertae_sedis" title="Incertae sedis">incertae sedis</a></i>: <a href="/wiki/Aardvark" title="Aardvark">aardvark</a></li>
<li>Mirorder <a href="/wiki/Eparctocyona" title="Eparctocyona">Eparctocyona</a>: †<a href="/wiki/Condylarth" title="Condylarth">condylarths</a>, <a href="/wiki/Whale" title="Whale">whales</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Artiodactyla" title="Artiodactyla">artiodactyls</a> (even-toed ungulates)</li>
<li>Mirorder †<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Meridiungulata" title="Meridiungulata">Meridiungulata</a>: South American ungulates</li>
<li>Mirorder <a href="/wiki/Altungulata" title="Altungulata">Altungulata</a>: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Perissodactyla" title="Perissodactyla">perissodactyls</a> (odd-toed ungulates), <a href="/wiki/Elephant" title="Elephant">elephants</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manatee" title="Manatee">manatees</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hyrax" title="Hyrax">hyraxes</a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Molecular_classification_of_placentals">Molecular classification of placentals</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1481" data-file-width="1674" decoding="async" height="265" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg/300px-OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg/450px-OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg/600px-OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Genus-level molecular phylogeny of 116 extant mammals inferred from the gene tree information of 14,509 <a href="/wiki/Coding_region" title="Coding region">coding DNA sequences</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scornavacca2019_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scornavacca2019-16">[16]</a></sup> The major clades are colored: Marsupials (magenta), Xenarthrans (orange), afrotherians (red), laurasiatherians (green), and euarchontoglires (blue).</div></div></div>
<p>As of the early 21st century, molecular studies based on <a href="/wiki/DNA" title="DNA">DNA</a> analysis have suggested new relationships among mammal families. Most of these findings have been independently validated by <a href="/wiki/Retrotransposon" title="Retrotransposon">retrotransposon</a> <a href="/wiki/Retrotransposon_marker" title="Retrotransposon marker">presence/absence data</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kriegs2006_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kriegs2006-17">[17]</a></sup> Classification systems based on molecular studies reveal three major groups or lineages of placental mammals—<a href="/wiki/Afrotheria" title="Afrotheria">Afrotheria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xenarthra" title="Xenarthra">Xenarthra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Boreoeutheria" title="Boreoeutheria">Boreoeutheria</a>—which <a href="/wiki/Speciation" title="Speciation">diverged</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous" title="Cretaceous">Cretaceous</a>. The relationships between these three lineages is contentious, and all three possible hypotheses have been proposed with respect to which group is <a href="/wiki/Basal_(phylogenetics)" title="Basal (phylogenetics)">basal</a>. These hypotheses are <a href="/wiki/Atlantogenata" title="Atlantogenata">Atlantogenata</a> (basal Boreoeutheria), <a href="/wiki/Epitheria" title="Epitheria">Epitheria</a> (basal Xenarthra) and <a href="/wiki/Exafroplacentalia" title="Exafroplacentalia">Exafroplacentalia</a> (basal Afrotheria).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nishiharaetal2009_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nishiharaetal2009-18">[18]</a></sup> Boreoeutheria in turn contains two major lineages—<a href="/wiki/Euarchontoglires" title="Euarchontoglires">Euarchontoglires</a> and <a href="/wiki/Laurasiatheria" title="Laurasiatheria">Laurasiatheria</a>.
</p><p>Estimates for the divergence times between these three placental groups range from 105 to 120 million years ago, depending on the type of DNA used (such as <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_DNA" title="Nuclear DNA">nuclear</a> or <a href="/wiki/Mitochondrial_DNA" title="Mitochondrial DNA">mitochondrial</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> and varying interpretations of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paleogeographic" title="Paleogeographic">paleogeographic</a> data.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nishiharaetal2009_18-1"><a href="#cite_note-Nishiharaetal2009-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r984819063">.mw-parser-output table.clade{border-spacing:0;margin:0;font-size:100%;line-height:100%;border-collapse:separate;width:auto}.mw-parser-output table.clade table.clade{width:100%;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-label{width:0.7em;padding:0 0.15em;vertical-align:bottom;text-align:center;border-left:1px solid;border-bottom:1px solid;white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-fixed-width{overflow:hidden;text-overflow:ellipsis}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-fixed-width:hover{overflow:visible}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-label.first{border-left:none;border-right:none}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-label.reverse{border-left:none;border-right:1px solid}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-slabel{padding:0 0.15em;vertical-align:top;text-align:center;border-left:1px solid;white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-slabel:hover{overflow:visible}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-slabel.last{border-left:none;border-right:none}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-slabel.reverse{border-left:none;border-right:1px solid}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-bar{vertical-align:middle;text-align:left;padding:0 0.5em;position:relative}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-bar.reverse{text-align:right;position:relative}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-leaf{border:0;padding:0;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-leafR{border:0;padding:0;text-align:right}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-leaf.reverse{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output table.clade:hover span.linkA{background-color:yellow}.mw-parser-output table.clade:hover span.linkB{background-color:green}</style>

</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>

<p>The <a href="/wiki/Cladogram" title="Cladogram">cladogram</a> above is based on Tarver <i>et al</i>. (2016)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Evolution">Evolution</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Evolution_of_mammals" title="Evolution of mammals">Evolution of mammals</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Origins">Origins</span></h3>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Synapsida" title="Synapsida">Synapsida</a>, a clade that contains mammals and their extinct relatives, originated during the <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvanian_(geology)" title="Pennsylvanian (geology)">Pennsylvanian subperiod</a> (~323 million to ~300 million years ago), when they split from the reptile lineage. Crown group mammals evolved from earlier <a href="/wiki/Mammaliaformes" title="Mammaliaformes">mammaliaforms</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Early_Jurassic" title="Early Jurassic">Early Jurassic</a>. The cladogram takes Mammalia to be the crown group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Liaoconodon2011_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-Liaoconodon2011-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"><a href="/wiki/Mammaliaformes" title="Mammaliaformes">Mammaliaformes</a>
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Morganucodontidae" title="Morganucodontidae">Morganucodontidae</a> <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Morganucodon.jpg"><img alt="Morganucodon.jpg" data-file-height="978" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="24" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Morganucodon.jpg/50px-Morganucodon.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Morganucodon.jpg/75px-Morganucodon.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Morganucodon.jpg/100px-Morganucodon.jpg 2x" width="50"/></a>
</p>
</td></tr>
