<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Evolution_from_older_amniotes">Evolution from older amniotes</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Skull_synapsida_1.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="260" data-file-width="568" decoding="async" height="101" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Skull_synapsida_1.png/220px-Skull_synapsida_1.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Skull_synapsida_1.png/330px-Skull_synapsida_1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Skull_synapsida_1.png/440px-Skull_synapsida_1.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Skull_synapsida_1.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The original synapsid skull structure contains one <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temporal_fenestrae" title="Temporal fenestrae">temporal opening</a> behind the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eye_socket" title="Eye socket">orbitals</a>, in a fairly low position on the skull (lower right in this image). This opening might have assisted in containing the jaw muscles of these organisms which could have increased their biting strength.</div></div></div>
<p>The first fully terrestrial <a href="/wiki/Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate">vertebrates</a> were <a href="/wiki/Amniote" title="Amniote">amniotes</a>. Like their amphibious early <a href="/wiki/Tetrapod" title="Tetrapod">tetrapod</a> predecessors, they had lungs and limbs. Amniotic eggs, however, have internal membranes that allow the developing <a href="/wiki/Embryo" title="Embryo">embryo</a> to breathe but keep water in. Hence, amniotes can lay eggs on dry land, while amphibians generally need to lay their eggs in water.
</p><p>The first amniotes apparently arose in the Pennsylvanian subperiod of the <a href="/wiki/Carboniferous" title="Carboniferous">Carboniferous</a>. They descended from earlier <a href="/wiki/Reptiliomorpha" title="Reptiliomorpha">reptiliomorph</a> amphibious tetrapods,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AhlbergMilner1994OriginOfTetrapods_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-AhlbergMilner1994OriginOfTetrapods-22">[22]</a></sup> which lived on land that was already inhabited by <a href="/wiki/Insect" title="Insect">insects</a> and other invertebrates as well as <a href="/wiki/Fern" title="Fern">ferns</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moss" title="Moss">mosses</a> and other plants. Within a few million years, two important amniote lineages became distinct: the <a href="/wiki/Synapsid" title="Synapsid">synapsids</a>, which would later include the common ancestor of the mammals; and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sauropsid" title="Sauropsid">sauropsids</a>, which now include <a href="/wiki/Turtle" title="Turtle">turtles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lizard" title="Lizard">lizards</a>, <a href="/wiki/Snake" title="Snake">snakes</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crocodilian" title="Crocodilian">crocodilians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dinosaur" title="Dinosaur">dinosaurs</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Bird" title="Bird">birds</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Synapsids have a single hole (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temporal_fenestra" title="Temporal fenestra">temporal fenestra</a>) low on each side of the skull. Primitive synapsids included the largest and fiercest animals of the early <a href="/wiki/Permian" title="Permian">Permian</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Dimetrodon" title="Dimetrodon">Dimetrodon</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> Nonmammalian synapsids were traditionally – and incorrectly – called "mammal-like reptiles" or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pelycosaurs" title="Pelycosaurs">pelycosaurs</a>; we now know they were neither reptiles nor part of reptile lineage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kemp2006_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kemp2006-25">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bennett1986_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bennett1986-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Therapsid" title="Therapsid">Therapsids</a>, a group of synapsids, evolved in the <a href="/wiki/Guadalupian" title="Guadalupian">Middle Permian</a>, about 265 million years ago, and became the dominant land vertebrates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kemp2006_25-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kemp2006-25">[25]</a></sup> They differ from basal <a href="/wiki/Eupelycosauria" title="Eupelycosauria">eupelycosaurs</a> in several features of the skull and jaws, including: larger skulls and <a href="/wiki/Incisor" title="Incisor">incisors</a> which are equal in size in therapsids, but not for eupelycosaurs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kemp2006_25-2"><a href="#cite_note-Kemp2006-25">[25]</a></sup> The therapsid lineage leading to mammals went through a series of stages, beginning with animals that were very similar to their early synapsid ancestors and ending with <a href="/wiki/Probainognathia" title="Probainognathia">probainognathian</a> <a href="/wiki/Cynodont" title="Cynodont">cynodonts</a>, some of which could easily be mistaken for mammals. Those stages were characterized by:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kermack1984_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kermack1984-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>The gradual development of a bony secondary <a href="/wiki/Hard_palate" title="Hard palate">palate</a>.</li>
<li>Abrupt acquisition of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endothermy" title="Endothermy">endothermy</a> among <a href="/wiki/Mammaliamorpha" title="Mammaliamorpha">Mammaliamorpha</a>, thus prior to the origin of mammals by 30-50 millions of years <i><b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup></b></i>.</li>
<li>Progression towards an erect limb posture, which would increase the animals' stamina by avoiding <a href="/wiki/Carrier%27s_constraint" title="Carrier's constraint">Carrier's constraint</a>. But this process was slow and erratic: for example, all herbivorous nonmammaliaform therapsids retained sprawling limbs (some late forms may have had semierect hind limbs); Permian carnivorous therapsids had sprawling forelimbs, and some late Permian ones also had semisprawling hindlimbs. In fact, modern monotremes still have semisprawling limbs.</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Mandible#In_other_vertebrates" title="Mandible">dentary</a> gradually became the main bone of the lower jaw which, by the Triassic, progressed towards the fully mammalian jaw (the lower consisting only of the dentary) and middle ear (which is constructed by the bones that were previously used to construct the jaws of reptiles).</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_mammals">First mammals</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Permian%E2%80%93Triassic_extinction_event" title="Permian–Triassic extinction event">Permian–Triassic extinction event</a> about 252 million years ago, which was a prolonged event due to the accumulation of several extinction pulses, ended the dominance of carnivorous therapsids.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> In the early Triassic, most medium to large land carnivore niches were taken over by <a href="/wiki/Archosaur" title="Archosaur">archosaurs</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> which, over an extended period (35 million years), came to include the <a href="/wiki/Crocodylomorpha" title="Crocodylomorpha">crocodylomorphs</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Pterosaur" title="Pterosaur">pterosaurs</a> and the dinosaurs;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> however, large cynodonts like <i><a href="/wiki/Trucidocynodon" title="Trucidocynodon">Trucidocynodon</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Traversodontidae" title="Traversodontidae">traversodontids</a> still occupied large sized carnivorous and herbivorous niches respectively. By the Jurassic, the dinosaurs had come to dominate the large terrestrial herbivore niches as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first mammals (in Kemp's sense) appeared in the Late Triassic epoch (about 225 million years ago), 40 million years after the first therapsids. They expanded out of their nocturnal <a href="/wiki/Insectivore" title="Insectivore">insectivore</a> niche from the mid-Jurassic onwards;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> The Jurassic <i><a href="/wiki/Castorocauda" title="Castorocauda">Castorocauda</a></i>, for example, was a close relative of true mammals that had adaptations for swimming, digging and catching fish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> Most, if not all, are thought to have remained nocturnal (the <a href="/wiki/Nocturnal_bottleneck" title="Nocturnal bottleneck">nocturnal bottleneck</a>), accounting for much of the typical mammalian traits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> The majority of the mammal species that existed in the <a href="/wiki/Mesozoic" title="Mesozoic">Mesozoic Era</a> were multituberculates, eutriconodonts and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spalacotheriid" title="Spalacotheriid">spalacotheriids</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Luo2007_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-Luo2007-37">[37]</a></sup> The earliest known <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metatherian" title="Metatherian">metatherian</a> is <i><a href="/wiki/Sinodelphys" title="Sinodelphys">Sinodelphys</a></i>, found in 125 million-year-old <a href="/wiki/Early_Cretaceous" title="Early Cretaceous">Early Cretaceous</a> <a href="/wiki/Shale" title="Shale">shale</a> in China's northeastern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liaoning_Province" title="Liaoning Province">Liaoning Province</a>. The fossil is nearly complete and includes tufts of fur and imprints of soft tissues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Juramaia_NT.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="287" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Juramaia_NT.jpg/220px-Juramaia_NT.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Juramaia_NT.jpg/330px-Juramaia_NT.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Juramaia_NT.jpg/440px-Juramaia_NT.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Juramaia_NT.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Restoration of <i><a href="/wiki/Juramaia" title="Juramaia">Juramaia sinensis</a></i>, the oldest known <a href="/wiki/Eutheria" title="Eutheria">Eutherian</a> (160 M.Y.A.)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Juramaia_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-Juramaia-39">[39]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The oldest known fossil among the <a href="/wiki/Eutheria" title="Eutheria">Eutheria</a> ("true beasts") is the small shrewlike <i><a href="/wiki/Juramaia" title="Juramaia">Juramaia sinensis</a></i>, or "Jurassic mother from China", dated to 160 million years ago in the late Jurassic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Juramaia_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-Juramaia-39">[39]</a></sup> A later eutherian relative, <i><a href="/wiki/Eomaia" title="Eomaia">Eomaia</a></i>, dated to 125 million years ago in the early Cretaceous, possessed some features in common with the marsupials but not with the placentals, evidence that these features were present in the last common ancestor of the two groups but were later lost in the placental lineage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> In particular, the <a href="/wiki/Epipubic_bone" title="Epipubic bone">epipubic bones</a> extend forwards from the pelvis. These are not found in any modern placental, but they are found in marsupials, monotremes, other nontherian mammals and <i><a href="/wiki/Ukhaatherium" title="Ukhaatherium">Ukhaatherium</a></i>, an early Cretaceous animal in the eutherian order <a href="/wiki/Asioryctitheria" title="Asioryctitheria">Asioryctitheria</a>. This also applies to the multituberculates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Epipubic_bones_in_eutherian_mammals_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-Epipubic_bones_in_eutherian_mammals-41">[41]</a></sup> They are apparently an ancestral feature, which subsequently disappeared in the placental lineage. These epipubic bones seem to function by stiffening the muscles during locomotion, reducing the amount of space being presented, which placentals require to contain their <a href="/wiki/Fetus" title="Fetus">fetus</a> during gestation periods. A narrow pelvic outlet indicates that the young were very small at birth and therefore <a href="/wiki/Pregnancy_(mammals)" title="Pregnancy (mammals)">pregnancy</a> was short, as in modern marsupials. This suggests that the placenta was a later development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>One of the earliest known monotremes was <i><a href="/wiki/Teinolophos" title="Teinolophos">Teinolophos</a></i>, which lived about 120 million years ago in Australia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> Monotremes have some features which may be inherited from the original amniotes such as the same orifice to urinate, defecate and reproduce (<a href="/wiki/Cloaca" title="Cloaca">cloaca</a>)—as lizards and birds also do—<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> and they lay <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Egg_(biology)" title="Egg (biology)">eggs</a> which are leathery and uncalcified.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Earliest_appearances_of_features">Earliest appearances of features</span></h3>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Hadrocodium" title="Hadrocodium">Hadrocodium</a></i>, whose fossils date from approximately 195 million years ago, in the early <a href="/wiki/Jurassic" title="Jurassic">Jurassic</a>, provides the first clear evidence of a jaw joint formed solely by the squamosal and dentary bones; there is no space in the jaw for the articular, a bone involved in the jaws of all early synapsids.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jawbone2006_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-jawbone2006-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="315" data-file-width="840" decoding="async" height="83" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg/220px-Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg/330px-Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg/440px-Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Fossil of <i><a href="/wiki/Thrinaxodon" title="Thrinaxodon">Thrinaxodon</a></i> at the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Natural_History" title="National Museum of Natural History">National Museum of Natural History</a></div></div></div>
<p>The earliest clear evidence of hair or fur is in fossils of <i><a href="/wiki/Castorocauda" title="Castorocauda">Castorocauda</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Megaconus" title="Megaconus">Megaconus</a></i>, from 164 million years ago in the mid-Jurassic. In the 1950s, it was suggested that the foramina (passages) in the <a href="/wiki/Maxilla" title="Maxilla">maxillae</a> and <a href="/wiki/Premaxilla" title="Premaxilla">premaxillae</a> (bones in the front of the upper jaw) of cynodonts were channels which supplied blood vessels and nerves to vibrissae (<a href="/wiki/Whiskers" title="Whiskers">whiskers</a>) and so were evidence of hair or fur;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brink1955_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brink1955-47">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kemp1982_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kemp1982-48">[48]</a></sup> it was soon pointed out, however, that foramina do not necessarily show that an animal had vibrissae, as the modern lizard <i><a href="/wiki/Tupinambis" title="Tupinambis">Tupinambis</a></i> has foramina that are almost identical to those found in the nonmammalian cynodont <i><a href="/wiki/Thrinaxodon" title="Thrinaxodon">Thrinaxodon</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bennett1986_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bennett1986-26">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> Popular sources, nevertheless, continue to attribute whiskers to <i>Thrinaxodon</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> Studies on Permian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coprolites" title="Coprolites">coprolites</a> suggest that non-mammalian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Synapsids" title="Synapsids">synapsids</a> of the epoch already had fur, setting the evolution of hairs possibly as far back as <a href="/wiki/Dicynodont" title="Dicynodont">dicynodonts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-piotr_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-piotr-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>When <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endothermy" title="Endothermy">endothermy</a> first appeared in the evolution of mammals is uncertain, though it is generally agreed to have first evolved in non-mammalian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Therapsids" title="Therapsids">therapsids</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-piotr_51-1"><a href="#cite_note-piotr-51">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> Modern monotremes have lower body temperatures and more variable metabolic rates than marsupials and placentals,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paul1988_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-Paul1988-53">[53]</a></sup> but there is evidence that some of their ancestors, perhaps including ancestors of the therians, may have had body temperatures like those of modern therians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> Likewise, some modern therians like afrotheres and xenarthrans have secondarily developed lower body temperatures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>The evolution of erect limbs in mammals is incomplete—living and fossil monotremes have sprawling limbs. The parasagittal (nonsprawling) limb posture appeared sometime in the late Jurassic or early Cretaceous; it is found in the eutherian <i>Eomaia</i> and the metatherian <i>Sinodelphys</i>, both dated to 125 million years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Epipubic" title="Epipubic">Epipubic</a> bones, a feature that strongly influenced the reproduction of most mammal clades, are first found in <a href="/wiki/Tritylodontidae" title="Tritylodontidae">Tritylodontidae</a>, suggesting that it is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Synapomorphy" title="Synapomorphy">synapomorphy</a> between them and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mammaliformes" title="Mammaliformes">mammaliformes</a>. They are omnipresent in non-placental mammaliformes, though <i><a href="/wiki/Megazostrodon" title="Megazostrodon">Megazostrodon</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Erythrotherium" title="Erythrotherium">Erythrotherium</a></i> appear to have lacked them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>It has been suggested that the original function of <a href="/wiki/Lactation" title="Lactation">lactation</a> (<a href="/wiki/Milk" title="Milk">milk</a> production) was to keep eggs moist. Much of the argument is based on monotremes, the egg-laying mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> In human females, mammary glands become fully developed during puberty, regardless of pregnancy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rise_of_the_mammals">Rise of the mammals</span></h3>
<p>Therian mammals took over the medium- to large-sized ecological niches in the <a href="/wiki/Cenozoic" title="Cenozoic">Cenozoic</a>, after the <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous%E2%80%93Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event">Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event</a> approximately 66 million years ago emptied ecological space once filled by non-avian dinosaurs and other groups of reptiles, as well as various other mammal groups,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates-61">[61]</a></sup> and underwent an exponential increase in body size (<a href="/wiki/Megafauna#In_terrestrial_mammals" title="Megafauna">megafauna</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-F.A.Smith_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-F.A.Smith-62">[62]</a></sup> Then mammals diversified very quickly; both birds and mammals show an exponential rise in diversity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates_61-1"><a href="#cite_note-SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates-61">[61]</a></sup> For example, the earliest known bat dates from about 50 million years ago, only 16 million years after the extinction of the non-avian dinosaurs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>Molecular phylogenetic studies initially suggested that most placental orders diverged about 100 to 85 million years ago and that modern families appeared in the period from the late <a href="/wiki/Eocene" title="Eocene">Eocene</a> through the <a href="/wiki/Miocene" title="Miocene">Miocene</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bininda2007_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bininda2007-64">[64]</a></sup> However, no placental fossils have been found from before the end of the Cretaceous.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wible2007_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wible2007-65">[65]</a></sup> The earliest undisputed fossils of placentals comes from the early <a href="/wiki/Paleocene" title="Paleocene">Paleocene</a>, after the extinction of the non-avian dinosaurs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wible2007_65-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wible2007-65">[65]</a></sup> In particular, scientists have identified an early Paleocene animal named <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protungulatum_donnae" title="Protungulatum donnae">Protungulatum donnae</a></i> as one of the first placental mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SCI-20130208_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-SCI-20130208-66">[66]</a></sup> however it has been reclassified as a non-placental eutherian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> Recalibrations of genetic and morphological diversity rates have suggested a <a href="/wiki/Maastrichtian" title="Maastrichtian">Late Cretaceous</a> origin for placentals, and a Paleocene origin for most modern clades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>The earliest known ancestor of primates is <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Archicebus_achilles" title="Archicebus achilles">Archicebus achilles</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NTR-20130606_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-NTR-20130606-69">[69]</a></sup> from around 55 million years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NTR-20130606_69-1"><a href="#cite_note-NTR-20130606-69">[69]</a></sup> This tiny primate weighed 20–30 grams (0.7–1.1 ounce) and could fit within a human palm.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NTR-20130606_69-2"><a href="#cite_note-NTR-20130606-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p><span class="anchor" id="Anatomy_and_morphology"></span>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Anatomy">Anatomy</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Distinguishing_features">Distinguishing features</span></h3>
<p>Living mammal species can be identified by the presence of <a href="/wiki/Sweat_gland" title="Sweat gland">sweat glands</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Mammary_gland" title="Mammary gland">those that are specialized to produce milk</a> to nourish their young.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> In classifying fossils, however, other features must be used, since soft tissue glands and many other features are not visible in fossils.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many traits shared by all living mammals appeared among the earliest members of the group:
</p>
<ul><li><b><a href="/wiki/Jaw" title="Jaw">Jaw joint</a></b> – The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dentary" title="Dentary">dentary</a> (the lower jaw bone, which carries the teeth) and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Squamosal" title="Squamosal">squamosal</a> (a small <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cranium" title="Cranium">cranial</a> bone) meet to form the joint. In most <a href="/wiki/Gnathostomata" title="Gnathostomata">gnathostomes</a>, including early <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Therapsida" title="Therapsida">therapsids</a>, the joint consists of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Articular" title="Articular">articular</a> (a small bone at the back of the lower jaw) and <a href="/wiki/Quadrate_bone" title="Quadrate bone">quadrate</a> (a small bone at the back of the upper jaw).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jawbone2006_46-1"><a href="#cite_note-jawbone2006-46">[46]</a></sup></li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Middle_ear" title="Middle ear">Middle ear</a></b> – In crown-group mammals, sound is carried from the <a href="/wiki/Eardrum" title="Eardrum">eardrum</a> by a chain of three bones, the <a href="/wiki/Malleus" title="Malleus">malleus</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Incus" title="Incus">incus</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Stapes" title="Stapes">stapes</a>. Ancestrally, the malleus and the incus are derived from the articular and the quadrate bones that constituted the jaw joint of early therapsids.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup></li>
<li><b>Tooth replacement</b> – Teeth can be replaced once (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diphyodonty" title="Diphyodonty">diphyodonty</a>) or (as in toothed whales and <a href="/wiki/Muridae" title="Muridae">murid</a> rodents) not at all (<a href="/wiki/Dentition" title="Dentition">monophyodonty</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> Elephants, manatees, and kangaroos continually grow new teeth throughout their life (<a href="/wiki/Polyphyodont" title="Polyphyodont">polyphyodonty</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup></li>
<li><b>Prismatic enamel</b> – The <a href="/wiki/Tooth_enamel" title="Tooth enamel">enamel</a> coating on the surface of a tooth consists of prisms, solid, rod-like structures extending from the <a href="/wiki/Dentin" title="Dentin">dentin</a> to the tooth's surface.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup></li>
<li><b><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occipital_condyle" title="Occipital condyle">Occipital condyles</a></b> – Two knobs at the base of the skull fit into the topmost <a href="/wiki/Cervical_vertebrae" title="Cervical vertebrae">neck vertebra</a>; most other <a href="/wiki/Tetrapod" title="Tetrapod">tetrapods</a>, in contrast, have only one such knob.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>For the most part, these characteristics were not present in the Triassic ancestors of the mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> Nearly all mammaliaforms possess an epipubic bone, the exception being modern placentals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-schulkin_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-schulkin-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sexual_dimorphism">Sexual dimorphism</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aurochsfeatures.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="776" data-file-width="1041" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aurochsfeatures.jpg/220px-Aurochsfeatures.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aurochsfeatures.jpg/330px-Aurochsfeatures.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aurochsfeatures.jpg/440px-Aurochsfeatures.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aurochsfeatures.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sexual dimorphism in <a href="/wiki/Aurochs" title="Aurochs">aurochs</a>, the extinct wild ancestor of <a href="/wiki/Cattle" title="Cattle">cattle</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>On average, male mammals are larger than females, with males being at least 10% larger than females in over 45% of investigated species. Most mammalian orders also exhibit male-biased <a href="/wiki/Sexual_dimorphism" title="Sexual dimorphism">sexual dimorphism</a>, although some orders do not show any bias or are significantly female-biased (<a href="/wiki/Lagomorpha" title="Lagomorpha">Lagomorpha</a>). Sexual size dimorphism increases with body size across mammals (<a href="/wiki/Rensch%27s_rule" title="Rensch's rule">Rensch's rule</a>), suggesting that there are parallel selection pressures on both male and female size. Male-biased dimorphism relates to sexual selection on males through male–male competition for females, as there is a positive correlation between the degree of sexual selection, as indicated by mating systems, and the degree of male-biased size dimorphism. The degree of sexual selection is also positively correlated with male and female size across mammals. Further, parallel selection pressure on female mass is identified in that age at weaning is significantly higher in more <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polygynous" title="Polygynous">polygynous</a> species, even when correcting for body mass. Also, the reproductive rate is lower for larger females, indicating that fecundity selection selects for smaller females in mammals. Although these patterns hold across mammals as a whole, there is considerable variation across orders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biological_systems">Biological systems</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Biological_system" title="Biological system">Biological system</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="399" data-file-width="620" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif/220px-Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif/330px-Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif/440px-Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Raccoon lungs being inflated manually</div></div></div>
<p>The majority of mammals have seven <a href="/wiki/Cervical_vertebrae" title="Cervical vertebrae">cervical vertebrae</a> (bones in the neck). The exceptions are the <a href="/wiki/Manatee" title="Manatee">manatee</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Two-toed_sloth" title="Two-toed sloth">two-toed sloth</a>, which have six, and the <a href="/wiki/Three-toed_sloth" title="Three-toed sloth">three-toed sloth</a> which has nine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> All mammalian brains possess a <a href="/wiki/Neocortex" title="Neocortex">neocortex</a>, a brain region unique to mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> Placental brains have a <a href="/wiki/Corpus_callosum" title="Corpus callosum">corpus callosum</a>, unlike monotremes and marsupials.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Lung" title="Lung">lungs</a> of mammals are spongy and honeycombed. Breathing is mainly achieved with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diaphragm_(anatomy)" title="Diaphragm (anatomy)">diaphragm</a>, which divides the thorax from the abdominal cavity, forming a dome convex to the thorax. Contraction of the diaphragm flattens the dome, increasing the volume of the lung cavity. Air enters through the oral and nasal cavities, and travels through the larynx, trachea and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bronchi" title="Bronchi">bronchi</a>, and expands the <a href="/wiki/Pulmonary_alveolus" title="Pulmonary alveolus">alveoli</a>. Relaxing the diaphragm has the opposite effect, decreasing the volume of the lung cavity, causing air to be pushed out of the lungs. During exercise, the abdominal wall <a href="/wiki/Muscle_contraction" title="Muscle contraction">contracts</a>, increasing pressure on the diaphragm, which forces air out quicker and more forcefully. The <a href="/wiki/Rib_cage" title="Rib cage">rib cage</a> is able to expand and contract the chest cavity through the action of other respiratory muscles. Consequently, air is sucked into or expelled out of the lungs, always moving down its pressure gradient.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bellows_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-bellows-84">[84]</a></sup> This type of lung is known as a bellows lung due to its resemblance to blacksmith <a href="/wiki/Bellows" title="Bellows">bellows</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bellows_84-1"><a href="#cite_note-bellows-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>The mammalian <a href="/wiki/Heart" title="Heart">heart</a> has four chambers, two upper <a href="/wiki/Atrium_(heart)" title="Atrium (heart)">atria</a>, the receiving chambers, and two lower <a href="/wiki/Ventricle_(heart)" title="Ventricle (heart)">ventricles</a>, the discharging chambers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> The heart has four valves, which separate its chambers and ensures blood flows in the correct direction through the heart (preventing backflow). After <a href="/wiki/Gas_exchange" title="Gas exchange">gas exchange</a> in the pulmonary capillaries (blood vessels in the lungs), oxygen-rich blood returns to the left atrium via one of the four <a href="/wiki/Pulmonary_vein" title="Pulmonary vein">pulmonary veins</a>. Blood flows nearly continuously back into the atrium, which acts as the receiving chamber, and from here through an opening into the left ventricle. Most blood flows passively into the heart while both the atria and ventricles are relaxed, but toward the end of the <a href="/wiki/Diastole" title="Diastole">ventricular relaxation period</a>, the left atrium will contract, pumping blood into the ventricle. The heart also requires nutrients and oxygen found in blood like other muscles, and is supplied via <a href="/wiki/Coronary_circulation" title="Coronary circulation">coronary arteries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p>
