width="100"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" decoding="async" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg/200px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg/300px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg/400px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" decoding="async" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg/200px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg/300px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg/400px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flow-root"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/Educational_toy" title="Educational toy">Didactic models</a> of a mammalian heart</div></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:237px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_skin_of_mammals.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="700" data-file-width="550" decoding="async" height="299" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/The_skin_of_mammals.jpg/235px-The_skin_of_mammals.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/The_skin_of_mammals.jpg/353px-The_skin_of_mammals.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/The_skin_of_mammals.jpg/470px-The_skin_of_mammals.jpg 2x" width="235"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_skin_of_mammals.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mammal skin: <i>1</i> — <a href="/wiki/Hair" title="Hair">hair</a>, <i>2</i> — <a href="/wiki/Epidermis" title="Epidermis">epidermis</a>, <i>3</i> — <a href="/wiki/Sebaceous_gland" title="Sebaceous gland">sebaceous gland</a>, <i>4</i> — <a href="/wiki/Arrector_pili_muscle" title="Arrector pili muscle">Arrector pili muscle</a>, <i>5</i> — <a href="/wiki/Dermis" title="Dermis">dermis</a>, <i>6</i> — <a href="/wiki/Hair_follicle" title="Hair follicle">hair follicle</a>, <i>7</i> — <a href="/wiki/Sweat_gland" title="Sweat gland">sweat gland</a>, 8 (not labeled, the bottom layer)  — <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hypodermis" title="Hypodermis">hypodermis</a>, showing round <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Adipocytes" title="Adipocytes">adipocytes</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Skin" title="Skin">integumentary system</a> (skin) is made up of three layers: the outermost <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Epidermis_(skin)" title="Epidermis (skin)">epidermis</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Dermis" title="Dermis">dermis</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hypodermis" title="Hypodermis">hypodermis</a>. The epidermis is typically 10 to 30 cells thick; its main function is to provide a waterproof layer. Its outermost cells are constantly lost; its bottommost cells are constantly dividing and pushing upward. The middle layer, the dermis, is 15 to 40 times thicker than the epidermis. The dermis is made up of many components, such as bony structures and blood vessels. The hypodermis is made up of <a href="/wiki/Adipose_tissue" title="Adipose tissue">adipose tissue</a>, which stores lipids and provides cushioning and insulation. The thickness of this layer varies widely from species to species;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-hair-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 97">: 97 </span></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marine_mammal" title="Marine mammal">marine mammals</a> require a thick hypodermis (<a href="/wiki/Blubber" title="Blubber">blubber</a>) for insulation, and <a href="/wiki/Right_whale" title="Right whale">right whales</a> have the thickest blubber at 20 inches (51 cm).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> Although other animals have features such as whiskers, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Feathers" title="Feathers">feathers</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Setae" title="Setae">setae</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Cilia_(entomology)" title="Cilia (entomology)">cilia</a> that superficially resemble it, no animals other than mammals have <a href="/wiki/Hair" title="Hair">hair</a>. It is a definitive characteristic of the class, though some mammals have very little.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-1"><a href="#cite_note-hair-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 61">: 61 </span></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aardwolfskull.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="284" data-file-width="402" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Aardwolfskull.jpg/200px-Aardwolfskull.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Aardwolfskull.jpg/300px-Aardwolfskull.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Aardwolfskull.jpg/400px-Aardwolfskull.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg/200px-Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg/300px-Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg/400px-Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Carnassial" title="Carnassial">carnassials</a> (teeth in the very back of the mouth) of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Insectivorous" title="Insectivorous">insectivorous</a> <a href="/wiki/Aardwolf" title="Aardwolf">aardwolf</a> (left) vs. that of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gray_wolf" title="Gray wolf">gray wolf</a> (right) which consumes large vertebrates</div></div></div></div>
<p>Herbivores have developed a diverse range of physical structures to facilitate the <a href="/wiki/Herbivore_adaptations_to_plant_defense" title="Herbivore adaptations to plant defense">consumption of plant material</a>. To break up intact plant tissues, mammals have developed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Teeth" title="Teeth">teeth</a> structures that reflect their feeding preferences. For instance, <a href="/wiki/Frugivore" title="Frugivore">frugivores</a> (animals that feed primarily on fruit) and herbivores that feed on soft foliage have low-crowned teeth specialized for grinding foliage and <a href="/wiki/Seed" title="Seed">seeds</a>. <a href="/wiki/Grazing" title="Grazing">Grazing</a> animals that tend to eat hard, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Silica" title="Silica">silica</a>-rich grasses, have high-crowned teeth, which are capable of grinding tough plant tissues and do not wear down as quickly as low-crowned teeth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> Most carnivorous mammals have <a href="/wiki/Carnassial" title="Carnassial">carnassialiforme</a> teeth (of varying length depending on diet), long canines and similar tooth replacement patterns.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>The stomach of <a href="/wiki/Even-toed_ungulate" title="Even-toed ungulate">even-toed ungulates</a> (Artiodactyla) is divided into four sections: the <a href="/wiki/Rumen" title="Rumen">rumen</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Reticulum_(anatomy)" title="Reticulum (anatomy)">reticulum</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Omasum" title="Omasum">omasum</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Abomasum" title="Abomasum">abomasum</a> (only <a href="/wiki/Ruminant" title="Ruminant">ruminants</a> have a rumen). After the plant material is consumed, it is mixed with saliva in the rumen and reticulum and separates into solid and liquid material. The solids lump together to form a <a href="/wiki/Bolus_(digestion)" title="Bolus (digestion)">bolus</a> (or <a href="/wiki/Cud" title="Cud">cud</a>), and is regurgitated. When the bolus enters the mouth, the fluid is squeezed out with the tongue and swallowed again. Ingested food passes to the rumen and reticulum where cellulolytic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Microbe" title="Microbe">microbes</a> (<a href="/wiki/Bacteria" title="Bacteria">bacteria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Protozoa" title="Protozoa">protozoa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fungus" title="Fungus">fungi</a>) produce <a href="/wiki/Cellulase" title="Cellulase">cellulase</a>, which is needed to break down the <a href="/wiki/Cellulose" title="Cellulose">cellulose</a> in plants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Comparative_anatomy_of_the_stomach_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-Comparative_anatomy_of_the_stomach-91">[91]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Odd-toed_ungulate" title="Odd-toed ungulate">Perissodactyls</a>, in contrast to the ruminants, store digested food that has left the stomach in an enlarged <a href="/wiki/Cecum" title="Cecum">cecum</a>, where it is fermented by bacteria.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> Carnivora have a simple stomach adapted to digest primarily meat, as compared to the elaborate digestive systems of herbivorous animals, which are necessary to break down tough, complex plant fibers. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caecum" title="Caecum">caecum</a> is either absent or short and simple, and the large intestine is not <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sacculation" title="Sacculation">sacculated</a> or much wider than the small intestine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg/220px-Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg/330px-Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg/440px-Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bovine kidney</div></div></div>
<p>The mammalian <a href="/wiki/Excretory_system" title="Excretory system">excretory system</a> involves many components. Like most other land animals, mammals are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ureotelic" title="Ureotelic">ureotelic</a>, and convert <a href="/wiki/Ammonia" title="Ammonia">ammonia</a> into <a href="/wiki/Urea" title="Urea">urea</a>, which is done by the <a href="/wiki/Liver" title="Liver">liver</a> as part of the <a href="/wiki/Urea_cycle" title="Urea cycle">urea cycle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bilirubin" title="Bilirubin">Bilirubin</a>, a waste product derived from <a href="/wiki/Blood_cell" title="Blood cell">blood cells</a>, is passed through <a href="/wiki/Bile" title="Bile">bile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urine" title="Urine">urine</a> with the help of enzymes excreted by the liver.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> The passing of bilirubin via bile through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intestinal_tract" title="Intestinal tract">intestinal tract</a> gives mammalian <a href="/wiki/Feces" title="Feces">feces</a> a distinctive brown coloration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> Distinctive features of the mammalian kidney include the presence of the <a href="/wiki/Renal_pelvis" title="Renal pelvis">renal pelvis</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Renal_pyramid" title="Renal pyramid">renal pyramids</a>, and of a clearly distinguishable <a href="/wiki/Renal_cortex" title="Renal cortex">cortex</a> and <a href="/wiki/Renal_medulla" title="Renal medulla">medulla</a>, which is due to the presence of elongated <a href="/wiki/Loop_of_Henle" title="Loop of Henle">loops of Henle</a>. Only the mammalian kidney has a bean shape, although there are some exceptions, such as the multilobed <a href="/wiki/Reniculate_kidney" title="Reniculate kidney">reniculate kidneys</a> of pinnipeds, <a href="/wiki/Cetacea" title="Cetacea">cetaceans</a> and bears.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VB_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-VB-98">[98]</a></sup> Most adult placental mammals have no remaining trace of the <a href="/wiki/Cloaca" title="Cloaca">cloaca</a>. In the embryo, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Embryonic_cloaca" title="Embryonic cloaca">embryonic cloaca</a> divides into a posterior region that becomes part of the anus, and an anterior region that has different fates depending on the sex of the individual: in females, it develops into the vestibule that receives the <a href="/wiki/Urethra" title="Urethra">urethra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vagina" title="Vagina">vagina</a>, while in males it forms the entirety of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Penile_urethra" title="Penile urethra">penile urethra</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VB_98-1"><a href="#cite_note-VB-98">[98]</a></sup> However, the <a href="/wiki/Tenrec" title="Tenrec">tenrecs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Golden_mole" title="Golden mole">golden moles</a>, and some <a href="/wiki/Shrew" title="Shrew">shrews</a> retain a cloaca as adults.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> In marsupials, the genital tract is separate from the anus, but a trace of the original cloaca does remain externally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VB_98-2"><a href="#cite_note-VB-98">[98]</a></sup> Monotremes, which translates from <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Greek</a> into "single hole", have a true cloaca.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sound_production">Sound production</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Animal_echolocation.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="245" data-file-width="318" decoding="async" height="231" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Animal_echolocation.svg/300px-Animal_echolocation.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Animal_echolocation.svg/450px-Animal_echolocation.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Animal_echolocation.svg/600px-Animal_echolocation.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Animal_echolocation.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A diagram of ultrasonic signals emitted by a bat, and the echo from a nearby object</div></div></div>
<p>As in all other tetrapods, mammals have a <a href="/wiki/Larynx" title="Larynx">larynx</a> that can quickly open and close to produce sounds, and a supralaryngeal <a href="/wiki/Vocal_tract" title="Vocal tract">vocal tract</a> which filters this sound. The lungs and surrounding musculature provide the air stream and pressure required to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Phonate" title="Phonate">phonate</a>. The larynx controls the <a href="/wiki/Pitch_(music)" title="Pitch (music)">pitch</a> and <a href="/wiki/Loudness" title="Loudness">volume</a> of sound, but the strength the lungs exert to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Exhale" title="Exhale">exhale</a> also contributes to volume. More primitive mammals, such as the echidna, can only hiss, as sound is achieved solely through exhaling through a partially closed larynx. Other mammals phonate using <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vocal_fold" title="Vocal fold">vocal folds</a>. The movement or tenseness of the vocal folds can result in many sounds such as <a href="/wiki/Purr" title="Purr">purring</a> and <a href="/wiki/Screaming" title="Screaming">screaming</a>. Mammals can change the position of the larynx, allowing them to breathe through the nose while swallowing through the mouth, and to form both oral and <a href="/wiki/Nasalization" title="Nasalization">nasal</a> sounds; nasal sounds, such as a dog whine, are generally soft sounds, and oral sounds, such as a dog bark, are generally loud.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fitchbrown2006_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-fitchbrown2006-101">[101]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><audio class="thumbimage" controls="" data-durationhint="17" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Beluga_vocalizations.ogg" id="mwe_player_0" preload="none" style="width:220px;" width="220"><source data-bandwidth="72834" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (73 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9f/Beluga_vocalizations.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="127568" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/9/9f/Beluga_vocalizations.ogg/Beluga_vocalizations.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/></audio> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beluga_vocalizations.ogg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Beluga_whale" title="Beluga whale">Beluga whale</a> echolocation sounds</div></div></div>
<p>Some mammals have a large larynx and thus a low-pitched voice, namely the <a href="/wiki/Hammer-headed_bat" title="Hammer-headed bat">hammer-headed bat</a> (<i>Hypsignathus monstrosus</i>) where the larynx can take up the entirety of the <a href="/wiki/Thoracic_cavity" title="Thoracic cavity">thoracic cavity</a> while pushing the lungs, heart, and trachea into the <a href="/wiki/Abdomen" title="Abdomen">abdomen</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> Large vocal pads can also lower the pitch, as in the low-pitched roars of <a href="/wiki/Big_cat" title="Big cat">big cats</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> The production of <a href="/wiki/Infrasound" title="Infrasound">infrasound</a> is possible in some mammals such as the <a href="/wiki/African_elephant" title="African elephant">African elephant</a> (<i>Loxodonta</i> spp.) and <a href="/wiki/Baleen_whale" title="Baleen whale">baleen whales</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> Small mammals with small larynxes have the ability to produce <a href="/wiki/Ultrasound" title="Ultrasound">ultrasound</a>, which can be detected by modifications to the <a href="/wiki/Middle_ear" title="Middle ear">middle ear</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cochlea" title="Cochlea">cochlea</a>. Ultrasound is inaudible to birds and reptiles, which might have been important during the Mesozoic, when birds and reptiles were the dominant predators. This private channel is used by some rodents in, for example, mother-to-pup communication, and by bats when echolocating. Toothed whales also use echolocation, but, as opposed to the vocal membrane that extends upward from the vocal folds, they have a <a href="/wiki/Melon_(cetacean)" title="Melon (cetacean)">melon</a> to manipulate sounds. Some mammals, namely the primates, have air sacs attached to the larynx, which may function to lower the resonances or increase the volume of sound.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fitchbrown2006_101-1"><a href="#cite_note-fitchbrown2006-101">[101]</a></sup>
</p><p>The vocal production system is controlled by the <a href="/wiki/Cranial_nerve_nucleus" title="Cranial nerve nucleus">cranial nerve nuclei</a> in the brain, and supplied by the <a href="/wiki/Recurrent_laryngeal_nerve" title="Recurrent laryngeal nerve">recurrent laryngeal nerve</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Superior_laryngeal_nerve" title="Superior laryngeal nerve">superior laryngeal nerve</a>, branches of the <a href="/wiki/Vagus_nerve" title="Vagus nerve">vagus nerve</a>. The vocal tract is supplied by the <a href="/wiki/Hypoglossal_nerve" title="Hypoglossal nerve">hypoglossal nerve</a> and <a href="/wiki/Facial_nerve" title="Facial nerve">facial nerves</a>. Electrical stimulation of the <a href="/wiki/Periaqueductal_gray" title="Periaqueductal gray">periaqueductal gray</a> (PEG) region of the mammalian <a href="/wiki/Midbrain" title="Midbrain">midbrain</a> elicit vocalizations. The ability to learn new vocalizations is only exemplified in humans, seals, cetaceans, elephants and possibly bats; in humans, this is the result of a direct connection between the <a href="/wiki/Motor_cortex" title="Motor cortex">motor cortex</a>, which controls movement, and the <a href="/wiki/Motor_neuron" title="Motor neuron">motor neurons</a> in the spinal cord.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fitchbrown2006_101-2"><a href="#cite_note-fitchbrown2006-101">[101]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fur">Fur</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Fur" title="Fur">Fur</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="269" data-file-width="613" decoding="async" height="97" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg/220px-Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg/330px-Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg/440px-Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Porcupine" title="Porcupine">Porcupines</a> use their <a href="/wiki/Spine_(zoology)" title="Spine (zoology)">spines</a> for defense.</div></div></div>
<p>The primary function of the fur of mammals is thermoregulation. Others include protection, sensory purposes, waterproofing, and camouflage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dawson2014_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-dawson2014-106">[106]</a></sup> Different types of fur serve different purposes:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-2"><a href="#cite_note-hair-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 99">: 99 </span></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>Definitive – which may be <a href="/wiki/Moulting" title="Moulting">shed</a> after reaching a certain length</li>
<li>Vibrissae – sensory hairs, most commonly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Whisker" title="Whisker">whiskers</a></li>
<li>Pelage – guard hairs, under-fur, and <a href="/wiki/Awn_hair" title="Awn hair">awn hair</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Spine_(zoology)" title="Spine (zoology)">Spines</a> – stiff guard hair used for defense (such as in <a href="/wiki/Porcupine" title="Porcupine">porcupines</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bristle" title="Bristle">Bristles</a> – long hairs usually used in visual signals. (such as a lion's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mane_(lion)" title="Mane (lion)">mane</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vellus_hair" title="Vellus hair">Velli</a> – often called "down fur" which insulates newborn mammals</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Wool" title="Wool">Wool</a> – long, soft and often curly</li></ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Thermoregulation">Thermoregulation</span></h4>
<p>Hair length is not a factor in thermoregulation: for example, some tropical mammals such as sloths have the same length of fur length as some arctic mammals but with less insulation; and, conversely, other tropical mammals with short hair have the same insulating value as arctic mammals. The denseness of fur can increase an animal's insulation value, and arctic mammals especially have dense fur; for example, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Musk_ox" title="Musk ox">musk ox</a> has guard hairs measuring 30 cm (12 in) as well as a dense underfur, which forms an airtight coat, allowing them to survive in temperatures of −40 °C (−40 °F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-3"><a href="#cite_note-hair-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 162–163">: 162–163 </span></sup> Some desert mammals, such as camels, use dense fur to prevent solar heat from reaching their skin, allowing the animal to stay cool; a camel's fur may reach 70 °C (158 °F) in the summer, but the skin stays at 40 °C (104 °F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-4"><a href="#cite_note-hair-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 188">: 188 </span></sup> <a href="/wiki/Aquatic_mammal" title="Aquatic mammal">Aquatic mammals</a>, conversely, trap air in their fur to conserve heat by keeping the skin dry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-5"><a href="#cite_note-hair-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 162–163">: 162–163 </span></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1400" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG/220px-Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG/330px-Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG/440px-Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Leopard" title="Leopard">leopard</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Disruptive_coloration" title="Disruptive coloration">disruptively colored</a> coat provides <a href="/wiki/Camouflage" title="Camouflage">camouflage</a> for this <a href="/wiki/Ambush_predator" title="Ambush predator">ambush predator</a>.</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Coloration">Coloration</span></h4>
<p>Mammalian coats are colored for a variety of reasons, the major selective pressures including <a href="/wiki/Camouflage" title="Camouflage">camouflage</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sexual_selection" title="Sexual selection">sexual selection</a>, communication, and thermoregulation. Coloration in both the hair and skin of mammals is mainly determined by the type and amount of <a href="/wiki/Melanin" title="Melanin">melanin</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eumelanin" title="Eumelanin">eumelanins</a> for brown and black colors and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pheomelanin" title="Pheomelanin">pheomelanin</a> for a range of yellowish to reddish colors, giving mammals an <a href="/wiki/Earth_tone" title="Earth tone">earth tone</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HiltonPond_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-HiltonPond-108">[108]</a></sup> Some mammals have more vibrant colors; certain monkeys such <a href="/wiki/Mandrill" title="Mandrill">mandrills</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vervet_monkey" title="Vervet monkey">vervet monkeys</a>, and oppossums such as the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_mouse_opossum" title="Mexican mouse opossum">Mexican mouse opossums</a> and <a href="/wiki/Derby%27s_woolly_opossum" title="Derby's woolly opossum">Derby's woolly opossums</a>, have blue skin due to <a href="/wiki/Structural_coloration" title="Structural coloration">light diffraction</a> in <a href="/wiki/Collagen" title="Collagen">collagen</a> fibers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prum2004_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-Prum2004-109">[109]</a></sup> Many sloths appear green because their fur hosts green <a href="/wiki/Algae" title="Algae">algae</a>; this may be a <a href="/wiki/Symbiosis" title="Symbiosis">symbiotic</a> relation that affords <a href="/wiki/Camouflage" title="Camouflage">camouflage</a> to the sloths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>Camouflage is a powerful influence in a large number of mammals, as it helps to conceal individuals from predators or prey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bioscience.oxfordjournals.org_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-bioscience.oxfordjournals.org-111">[111]</a></sup> In arctic and subarctic mammals such as the <a href="/wiki/Arctic_fox" title="Arctic fox">arctic fox</a> (<i>Alopex lagopus</i>), <a href="/wiki/Collared_lemming" title="Collared lemming">collared lemming</a> (<i>Dicrostonyx groenlandicus</i>), <a href="/wiki/Stoat" title="Stoat">stoat</a> (<i>Mustela erminea</i>), and <a href="/wiki/Snowshoe_hare" title="Snowshoe hare">snowshoe hare</a> (<i>Lepus americanus</i>), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seasonal_polyphenism" title="Seasonal polyphenism">seasonal color change</a> between brown in summer and white in winter is driven largely by camouflage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> Some arboreal mammals, notably primates and marsupials, have shades of violet, green, or blue skin on parts of their bodies, indicating some distinct advantage in their largely <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arboreal" title="Arboreal">arboreal</a> habitat due to <a href="/wiki/Convergent_evolution" title="Convergent evolution">convergent evolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prum2004_109-1"><a href="#cite_note-Prum2004-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Aposematism" title="Aposematism">Aposematism</a>, warning off possible predators, is the most likely explanation of the black-and-white pelage of many mammals which are able to defend themselves, such as in the foul-smelling <a href="/wiki/Skunk" title="Skunk">skunk</a> and the powerful and aggressive <a href="/wiki/Honey_badger" title="Honey badger">honey badger</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> Coat color is sometimes <a href="/wiki/Sexual_dimorphism" title="Sexual dimorphism">sexually dimorphic</a>, as in <a href="/wiki/Sexual_dimorphism_in_non-human_primates#Pelage_color_and_markings" title="Sexual dimorphism in non-human primates">many primate species</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> Differences in female and male coat color may indicate nutrition and hormone levels, important in mate selection.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eva.mpg.de_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-eva.mpg.de-115">[115]</a></sup> Coat color may influence the ability to retain heat, depending on how much light is reflected. Mammals with a darker colored coat can absorb more heat from solar radiation, and stay warmer, and some smaller mammals, such as <a href="/wiki/Vole" title="Vole">voles</a>, have darker fur in the winter. The white, pigmentless fur of arctic mammals, such as the polar bear, may reflect more solar radiation directly onto the skin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-6"><a href="#cite_note-hair-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 166–167">: 166–167 </span></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dawson2014_106-1"><a href="#cite_note-dawson2014-106">[106]</a></sup> The dazzling black-and-white striping of <a href="/wiki/Zebra" title="Zebra">zebras</a> appear to provide some protection from biting flies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Caro_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-Caro-116">[116]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reproductive_system">Reproductive system</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mammalian_reproduction" title="Mammalian reproduction">Mammalian reproduction</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Goat_family.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1067" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Goat_family.jpg/220px-Goat_family.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Goat_family.jpg/330px-Goat_family.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Goat_family.jpg/440px-Goat_family.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Goat_family.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Goat" title="Goat">Goat</a> kids stay with their mother until they are weaned.</div></div></div>
<p>Mammals are solely <a href="/wiki/Gonochorism" title="Gonochorism">gonochoric</a> (an animal is born with either male or female genitalia, as opposed to <a href="/wiki/Hermaphrodite" title="Hermaphrodite">hermaphrodites</a> where there is no such schism).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> In male placentals, the <a href="/wiki/Penis" title="Penis">penis</a> is used both for urination and copulation. Depending on the species, an <a href="/wiki/Erection" title="Erection">erection</a> may be fueled by blood flow into vascular, spongy tissue or by muscular action. A penis may be contained in a <a href="/wiki/Penile_sheath" title="Penile sheath">prepuce</a> when not erect, and some placentals also have a penis bone (<a href="/wiki/Baculum" title="Baculum">baculum</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lombardi1998_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lombardi1998-118">[118]</a></sup> Marsupials typically have forked penises,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tyndale-BiscoeRenfree1987_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tyndale-BiscoeRenfree1987-119">[119]</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/Echidna" title="Echidna">echidna</a> penis generally has four heads with only two functioning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Testes" title="Testes">testes</a> of most mammals descend into the <a href="/wiki/Scrotum" title="Scrotum">scrotum</a> which is typically posterior to the penis but is often anterior in marsupials. Female mammals generally have a <a href="/wiki/Clitoris" title="Clitoris">clitoris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Labia_majora" title="Labia majora">labia majora</a> and <a href="/wiki/Labia_minora" title="Labia minora">labia minora</a> on the outside, while the internal system contains paired <a href="/wiki/Oviduct" title="Oviduct">oviducts</a>, 1–2 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uteri" title="Uteri">uteri</a>, 1–2 <a href="/wiki/Cervix" title="Cervix">cervices</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Vagina" title="Vagina">vagina</a>. Marsupials have two lateral vaginas and a medial vagina. The "vagina" of monotremes is better understood as a "urogenital sinus". The uterine systems of placental mammals can vary between a duplex, where there are two uteri and cervices which open into the vagina, a bipartite, where two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uterine_horn" title="Uterine horn">uterine horns</a> have a single cervix that connects to the vagina, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bicornuate" title="Bicornuate">bicornuate</a>, which consists where two uterine horns that are connected distally but separate medially creating a Y-shape, and a simplex, which has a single uterus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-7"><a href="#cite_note-hair-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 220–221, 247">: 220–221, 247 </span></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="746" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="205" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg/220px-Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg/330px-Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg/440px-Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Matschie%27s_tree-kangaroo" title="Matschie's tree-kangaroo">Matschie's tree-kangaroo</a> with young in pouch</div></div></div>
<p>The ancestral condition for mammal reproduction is the birthing of relatively undeveloped, either through direct <a href="/wiki/Vivipary" title="Vivipary">vivipary</a> or a short period as soft-shelled eggs. This is likely due to the fact that the torso could not expand due to the presence of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Epipubic_bones" title="Epipubic bones">epipubic bones</a>. The oldest demonstration of this reproductive style is with <i><a href="/wiki/Kayentatherium" title="Kayentatherium">Kayentatherium</a></i>, which produced undeveloped <a href="/wiki/Perinate" title="Perinate">perinates</a>, but at much higher litter sizes than any modern mammal, 38 specimens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoffman&amp;Rowe_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hoffman&amp;Rowe-123">[123]</a></sup> Most modern mammals are <a href="/wiki/Viviparity" title="Viviparity">viviparous</a>, giving birth to live young. However, the five species of monotreme, the platypus and the four species of echidna, lay eggs. The monotremes have a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sex_determination_system" title="Sex determination system">sex determination system</a> different from that of most other mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> In particular, the <a href="/wiki/Sex_chromosome" title="Sex chromosome">sex chromosomes</a> of a platypus are more like those of a chicken than those of a therian mammal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>Viviparous mammals are in the subclass Theria; those living today are in the marsupial and placental infraclasses. Marsupials have a short <a href="/wiki/Gestation" title="Gestation">gestation</a> period, typically shorter than its <a href="/wiki/Estrous_cycle" title="Estrous cycle">estrous cycle</a> and generally giving birth to a number of undeveloped newborns that then undergo further development; in many species, this takes place within a pouch-like sac, the <a href="/wiki/Pouch_(marsupial)" title="Pouch (marsupial)">marsupium</a>, located in the front of the mother's <a href="/wiki/Abdomen" title="Abdomen">abdomen</a>. This is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Symplesiomorphy" title="Symplesiomorphy">plesiomorphic</a> condition among viviparous mammals; the presence of epipubic bones in all non-placental mammals prevents the expansion of the torso needed for full pregnancy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-schulkin_78-1"><a href="#cite_note-schulkin-78">[78]</a></sup> Even non-placental eutherians probably reproduced this way.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Epipubic_bones_in_eutherian_mammals_41-1"><a href="#cite_note-Epipubic_bones_in_eutherian_mammals-41">[41]</a></sup> The placentals give birth to relatively complete and developed young, usually after long gestation periods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> They get their name from the <a href="/wiki/Placenta" title="Placenta">placenta</a>, which connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall to allow nutrient uptake.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> In placental mammals, the epipubic is either completely lost or converted into the baculum; allowing the torso to be able to expand and thus birth developed offspring.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoffman&amp;Rowe_123-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hoffman&amp;Rowe-123">[123]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Mammary_gland" title="Mammary gland">mammary glands</a> of mammals are specialized to produce milk, the primary source of nutrition for newborns. The monotremes branched early from other mammals and do not have the <a href="/wiki/Nipple" title="Nipple">nipples</a> seen in most mammals, but they do have mammary glands. The young lick the milk from a mammary patch on the mother's belly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> Compared to placental mammals, the milk of marsupials changes greatly in both production rate and in nutrient composition, due to the underdeveloped young. In addition, the mammary glands have more autonomy allowing them to supply separate milks to young at different development stages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lactose" title="Lactose">Lactose</a> is the main sugar in placental mammal milk while monotreme and marsupial milk is dominated by <a href="/wiki/Oligosaccharide" title="Oligosaccharide">oligosaccharides</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Weaning" title="Weaning">Weaning</a> is the process in which a mammal becomes less dependent on their mother's milk and more on solid food.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Endothermy">Endothermy</span></h3>
<p>Nearly all mammals are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endothermy" title="Endothermy">endothermic</a> ("warm-blooded"). Most mammals also have hair to help keep them warm. Like birds, mammals can forage or hunt in weather and climates too cold for <a href="/wiki/Ectotherm" title="Ectotherm">ectothermic</a> ("cold-blooded") reptiles and insects. Endothermy requires plenty of food energy, so mammals eat more food per unit of body weight than most reptiles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> Small insectivorous mammals eat prodigious amounts for their size. A rare exception, the <a href="/wiki/Naked_mole-rat" title="Naked mole-rat">naked mole-rat</a> produces little metabolic heat, so it is considered an operational <a href="/wiki/Poikilotherm" title="Poikilotherm">poikilotherm</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> Birds are also endothermic, so endothermy is not unique to mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Species_lifespan">Species lifespan</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">Life expectancy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maximum_life_span" title="Maximum life span">Maximum life span</a></div>
<p>Among mammals, species maximum lifespan varies significantly (for example the <a href="/wiki/Shrew" title="Shrew">shrew</a> has a lifespan of two years, whereas the oldest <a href="/wiki/Bowhead_whale" title="Bowhead whale">bowhead whale</a> is recorded to be 211 years).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pmid19896964_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-pmid19896964-135">[135]</a></sup> Although the underlying basis for these lifespan differences is still uncertain, numerous studies indicate that the ability to <a href="/wiki/DNA_repair" title="DNA repair">repair DNA damage</a> is an important determinant of mammalian lifespan. In a 1974 study by Hart and Setlow,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pmid4526202_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-pmid4526202-136">[136]</a></sup> it was found that DNA excision repair capability increased systematically with species lifespan among seven mammalian species. Species lifespan was observed to be robustly correlated with the capacity to recognize DNA double-strand breaks as well as the level of the DNA repair protein <a href="/wiki/Ku80" title="Ku80">Ku80</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pmid19896964_135-1"><a href="#cite_note-pmid19896964-135">[135]</a></sup> In a study of the cells from sixteen mammalian species, genes employed in DNA repair were found to be <a href="/wiki/Downregulation_and_upregulation" title="Downregulation and upregulation">up-regulated</a> in the longer-lived species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pmid27874830_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-pmid27874830-137">[137]</a></sup> The cellular level of the DNA repair enzyme <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Poly_ADP_ribose_polymerase" title="Poly ADP ribose polymerase">poly ADP ribose polymerase</a> was found to correlate with species lifespan in a study of 13 mammalian species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pmid1465394_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-pmid1465394-138">[138]</a></sup> Three additional studies of a variety of mammalian species also reported a correlation between species lifespan and DNA repair capability.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pmid7266079_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-pmid7266079-139">[139]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pmid7060140_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-pmid7060140-140">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pmid3974310_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-pmid3974310-141">[141]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Locomotion">Locomotion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Animal_locomotion" title="Animal locomotion">Animal locomotion</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Terrestrial">Terrestrial</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Terrestrial_locomotion" title="Terrestrial locomotion">Terrestrial locomotion</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="200" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif/220px-Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dd/Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Running" title="Running">Running gait</a>. Photographs by <a href="/wiki/Eadweard_Muybridge" title="Eadweard Muybridge">Eadweard Muybridge</a>, 1887.</div></div></div>
<p>Most vertebrates—the amphibians, the reptiles and some mammals such as humans and bears—are <a href="/wiki/Plantigrade" title="Plantigrade">plantigrade</a>, walking on the whole of the underside of the foot. Many mammals, such as cats and dogs, are <a href="/wiki/Digitigrade" title="Digitigrade">digitigrade</a>, walking on their toes, the greater stride length allowing more speed. Digitigrade mammals are also often adept at quiet movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> Some animals such as <a href="/wiki/Horse" title="Horse">horses</a> are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unguligrade" title="Unguligrade">unguligrade</a>, walking on the tips of their toes. This even further increases their stride length and thus their speed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> A few mammals, namely the great apes, are also known to <a href="/wiki/Knuckle-walking" title="Knuckle-walking">walk on their knuckles</a>, at least for their front legs. <a href="/wiki/Giant_anteater" title="Giant anteater">Giant anteaters</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> and platypuses<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> are also knuckle-walkers. Some mammals are <a href="/wiki/Bipedalism" title="Bipedalism">bipeds</a>, using only two limbs for locomotion, which can be seen in, for example, humans and the great apes. Bipedal species have a larger field of vision than quadrupeds, conserve more energy and have the ability to manipulate objects with their hands, which aids in foraging. Instead of walking, some bipeds hop, such as kangaroos and <a href="/wiki/Kangaroo_rat" title="Kangaroo rat">kangaroo rats</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>Animals will use different gaits for different speeds, terrain and situations. For example, horses show four natural gaits, the slowest <a href="/wiki/Horse_gait" title="Horse gait">horse gait</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Horse_gait#Walk" title="Horse gait">walk</a>, then there are three faster gaits which, from slowest to fastest, are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trot_(horse_gait)" title="Trot (horse gait)">trot</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canter" title="Canter">canter</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Horse_gait#Gallop" title="Horse gait">gallop</a>. Animals may also have unusual gaits that are used occasionally, such as for moving sideways or backwards. For example, the main <a href="/wiki/Gait_(human)" title="Gait (human)">human gaits</a> are bipedal <a href="/wiki/Walking" title="Walking">walking</a> and <a href="/wiki/Running" title="Running">running</a>, but they employ many other gaits occasionally, including a four-legged <a href="/wiki/Crawling_(human)" title="Crawling (human)">crawl</a> in tight spaces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dagg_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-dagg-148">[148]</a></sup> Mammals show a vast range of <a href="/wiki/Gait" title="Gait">gaits</a>, the order that they place and lift their appendages in locomotion. Gaits can be grouped into categories according to their patterns of support sequence. For quadrupeds, there are three main categories: walking gaits, running gaits and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leaping_gaits" title="Leaping gaits">leaping gaits</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> Walking is the most common gait, where some feet are on the ground at any given time, and found in almost all legged animals. Running is considered to occur when at some points in the stride all feet are off the ground in a moment of suspension.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dagg_148-1"><a href="#cite_note-dagg-148">[148]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Arboreal">Arboreal</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Arboreal_locomotion" title="Arboreal locomotion">Arboreal locomotion</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brachiating_Gibbon_(Some_rights_reserved).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="333" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Brachiating_Gibbon_%28Some_rights_reserved%29.jpg/170px-Brachiating_Gibbon_%28Some_rights_reserved%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Brachiating_Gibbon_%28Some_rights_reserved%29.jpg/255px-Brachiating_Gibbon_%28Some_rights_reserved%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d2/Brachiating_Gibbon_%28Some_rights_reserved%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Brachiating_Gibbon_(Some_rights_reserved).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Gibbon" title="Gibbon">Gibbons</a> are very good <a href="/wiki/Brachiation" title="Brachiation">brachiators</a> because their elongated limbs enable them to easily swing and grasp on to branches.</div></div></div>
<p>Arboreal animals frequently have elongated limbs that help them cross gaps, reach fruit or other resources, test the firmness of support ahead and, in some cases, to <a href="/wiki/Brachiation" title="Brachiation">brachiate</a> (swing between trees).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cartmill_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cartmill-150">[150]</a></sup> Many arboreal species, such as tree porcupines, <a href="/wiki/Silky_anteater" title="Silky anteater">silky anteaters</a>, spider monkeys, and <a href="/wiki/Phalangeriformes" title="Phalangeriformes">possums</a>, use <a href="/wiki/Prehensile_tail" title="Prehensile tail">prehensile tails</a> to grasp branches. In the spider monkey, the tip of the tail has either a bare patch or adhesive pad, which provides increased friction. Claws can be used to interact with rough substrates and reorient the direction of forces the animal applies. This is what allows <a href="/wiki/Squirrel" title="Squirrel">squirrels</a> to climb tree trunks that are so large to be essentially flat from the perspective of such a small animal. However, claws can interfere with an animal's ability to grasp very small branches, as they may wrap too far around and prick the animal's own paw. Frictional gripping is used by primates, relying upon hairless fingertips. Squeezing the branch between the fingertips generates frictional force that holds the animal's hand to the branch. However, this type of grip depends upon the angle of the frictional force, thus upon the diameter of the branch, with larger branches resulting in reduced gripping ability. To control descent, especially down large diameter branches, some arboreal animals such as squirrels have evolved highly mobile ankle joints that permit rotating the foot into a 'reversed' posture. This allows the claws to hook into the rough surface of the bark, opposing the force of gravity. Small size provides many advantages to arboreal species: such as increasing the relative size of branches to the animal, lower center of mass, increased stability, lower mass (allowing movement on smaller branches) and the ability to move through more cluttered habitat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cartmill_150-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cartmill-150">[150]</a></sup> Size relating to weight affects gliding animals such as the <a href="/wiki/Sugar_glider" title="Sugar glider">sugar glider</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> Some species of primate, bat and all species of <a href="/wiki/Sloth" title="Sloth">sloth</a> achieve passive stability by hanging beneath the branch. Both pitching and tipping become irrelevant, as the only method of failure would be losing their grip.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cartmill_150-2"><a href="#cite_note-Cartmill-150">[150]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Aerial">Aerial</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aerial_locomotion" title="Aerial locomotion">Aerial locomotion</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><video class="thumbimage" controls="" data-durationhint="102" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm" height="169" id="mwe_player_1" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/300px--Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.jpg" preload="none" width="300"><source data-bandwidth="857072" data-framerate="0" data-height="480" data-shorttitle="VP9 480P" data-title="SD VP9 (480P)" data-transcodekey="480p.vp9.webm" data-width="854" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.480p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="373744" data-framerate="0" data-height="360" data-shorttitle="VP9 360P" data-title="VP9 (360P)" data-transcodekey="360p.vp9.webm" data-width="640" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.360p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"'/><source data-bandwidth="512920" data-framerate="0" data-height="360" data-shorttitle="WebM 360P" data-title="WebM (360P)" data-transcodekey="360p.webm" data-width="640" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.360p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/></video> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Slow-motion and normal speed of <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_fruit_bat" title="Egyptian fruit bat">Egyptian fruit bats</a> flying</div></div></div>
<p>Bats are the only mammals that can truly fly. They fly through the air at a constant speed by moving their wings up and down (usually with some fore-aft movement as well). Because the animal is in motion, there is some airflow relative to its body which, combined with the velocity of the wings, generates a faster airflow moving over the wing. This generates a lift force vector pointing forwards and upwards, and a drag force vector pointing rearwards and upwards. The upwards components of these counteract gravity, keeping the body in the air, while the forward component provides thrust to counteract both the drag from the wing and from the body as a whole.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>The wings of bats are much thinner and consist of more bones than those of birds, allowing bats to maneuver more accurately and fly with more lift and less drag.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-anders_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-anders-154">[154]</a></sup> By folding the wings inwards towards their body on the upstroke, they use 35% less energy during flight than birds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> The membranes are delicate, ripping easily; however, the tissue of the bat's membrane is able to regrow, such that small tears can heal quickly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> The surface of their wings is equipped with touch-sensitive receptors on small bumps called <a href="/wiki/Merkel_cell" title="Merkel cell">Merkel cells</a>, also found on human fingertips. These sensitive areas are different in bats, as each bump has a tiny hair in the center, making it even more sensitive and allowing the bat to detect and collect information about the air flowing over its wings, and to fly more efficiently by changing the shape of its wings in response.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Fossorial_and_subterranean">Fossorial and subterranean</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:187px;max-width:187px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:138px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wombat3.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Wombat3.jpg/185px-Wombat3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Wombat3.jpg/278px-Wombat3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Wombat3.jpg/370px-Wombat3.jpg 2x" width="185"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:201px;max-width:201px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:138px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ScalopusAquaticus.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1042" data-file-width="1500" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/ScalopusAquaticus.jpg/199px-ScalopusAquaticus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/ScalopusAquaticus.jpg/299px-ScalopusAquaticus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/ScalopusAquaticus.jpg/398px-ScalopusAquaticus.jpg 2x" width="199"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Semi-fossorial <a href="/wiki/Southern_hairy-nosed_wombat" title="Southern hairy-nosed wombat">wombat</a> (left) vs. fully fossorial <a href="/wiki/Eastern_mole" title="Eastern mole">eastern mole</a> (right)</div></div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Fossorial" title="Fossorial">Fossorial</a> and <a href="/wiki/Burrow" title="Burrow">Burrow</a></div>
<p>A fossorial (from Latin <i>fossor</i>, meaning "digger") is an animal adapted to digging which lives primarily, but not solely, underground. Some examples are <a href="/wiki/Badger" title="Badger">badgers</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Naked_mole-rat" title="Naked mole-rat">naked mole-rats</a>. Many <a href="/wiki/Rodent" title="Rodent">rodent</a> species are also considered fossorial because they live in burrows for most but not all of the day. Species that live exclusively underground are subterranean, and those with limited adaptations to a fossorial lifestyle sub-fossorial. Some organisms are fossorial to aid in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temperature_regulation" title="Temperature regulation">temperature regulation</a> while others use the underground habitat for protection from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Predator" title="Predator">predators</a> or for <a href="/wiki/Food_storage" title="Food storage">food storage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-158">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>Fossorial mammals have a fusiform body, thickest at the shoulders and tapering off at the tail and nose. Unable to see in the dark burrows, most have degenerated eyes, but degeneration varies between species; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pocket_gopher" title="Pocket gopher">pocket gophers</a>, for example, are only semi-fossorial and have very small yet functional eyes, in the fully fossorial <a href="/wiki/Marsupial_mole" title="Marsupial mole">marsupial mole</a> the eyes are degenerated and useless, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Talpa_(genus)" title="Talpa (genus)">talpa moles</a> have <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vestigial" title="Vestigial">vestigial</a> eyes and the <a href="/wiki/Cape_golden_mole" title="Cape golden mole">cape golden mole</a> has a layer of skin covering the eyes. External ears flaps are also very small or absent. Truly fossorial mammals have short, stout legs as strength is more important than speed to a burrowing mammal, but semi-fossorial mammals have <a href="/wiki/Cursorial" title="Cursorial">cursorial</a> legs. The front paws are broad and have strong claws to help in loosening dirt while excavating burrows, and the back paws have webbing, as well as claws, which aids in throwing loosened dirt backwards. Most have large incisors to prevent dirt from flying into their mouth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many fossorial mammals such as shrews, hedgehogs, and moles were classified under the now obsolete order <a href="/wiki/Insectivora" title="Insectivora">Insectivora</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Aquatic">Aquatic</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Aquatic_locomotion" title="Aquatic locomotion">Aquatic locomotion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marine_mammal" title="Marine mammal">Marine mammal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Aquatic_mammal" title="Aquatic mammal">Aquatic mammal</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><video class="thumbimage" controls="" data-durationhint="45" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv" height="147" id="mwe_player_2" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv/220px--Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv.jpg" preload="none" width="220"><source data-bandwidth="807688" data-framerate="29.97002997003" data-height="480" data-shorttitle="VP9 480P" data-title="SD VP9 (480P)" data-transcodekey="480p.vp9.webm" data-width="720" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv.480p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/></video> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A pod of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Short-beaked_common_dolphin" title="Short-beaked common dolphin">short-beaked common dolphins</a> swimming</div></div></div>
<p>Fully aquatic mammals, the cetaceans and <a href="/wiki/Sirenia" title="Sirenia">sirenians</a>, have lost their legs and have a tail fin to propel themselves through the water. Flipper movement is continuous. Whales swim by moving their tail fin and lower body up and down, propelling themselves through vertical movement, while their flippers are mainly used for steering. Their skeletal anatomy allows them to be fast swimmers. Most species have a <a href="/wiki/Dorsal_fin" title="Dorsal fin">dorsal fin</a> to prevent themselves from turning upside-down in the water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> The flukes of sirenians are raised up and down in long strokes to move the animal forward, and can be twisted to turn. The forelimbs are paddle-like flippers which aid in turning and slowing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semi-aquatic" title="Semi-aquatic">Semi-aquatic</a> mammals, like pinnipeds, have two pairs of flippers on the front and back, the fore-flippers and hind-flippers. The elbows and ankles are enclosed within the body.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Berta63_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-Berta63-164">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fish_2003_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fish_2003-165">[165]</a></sup> Pinnipeds have several adaptions for reducing <a href="/wiki/Drag_(physics)" title="Drag (physics)">drag</a>. In addition to their streamlined bodies, they have smooth networks of <a href="/wiki/Muscle_fascicle" title="Muscle fascicle">muscle bundles</a> in their skin that may increase <a href="/wiki/Laminar_flow" title="Laminar flow">laminar flow</a> and make it easier for them to slip through water. They also lack <a href="/wiki/Arrector_pili_muscle" title="Arrector pili muscle">arrector pili</a>, so their fur can be streamlined as they swim.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Riedman3_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-Riedman3-166">[166]</a></sup> They rely on their fore-flippers for locomotion in a wing-like manner similar to <a href="/wiki/Penguin" title="Penguin">penguins</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sea_turtles" title="Sea turtles">sea turtles</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fish1996_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fish1996-167">[167]</a></sup> Fore-flipper movement is not continuous, and the animal glides between each stroke.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fish_2003_165-1"><a href="#cite_note-Fish_2003-165">[165]</a></sup> Compared to terrestrial carnivorans, the fore-limbs are reduced in length, which gives the locomotor muscles at the shoulder and elbow joints greater mechanical advantage;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Berta63_164-1"><a href="#cite_note-Berta63-164">[164]</a></sup> the hind-flippers serve as stabilizers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Riedman3_166-1"><a href="#cite_note-Riedman3-166">[166]</a></sup> Other semi-aquatic mammals include beavers, <a href="/wiki/Hippopotamus" title="Hippopotamus">hippopotamuses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Otter" title="Otter">otters</a> and platypuses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> Hippos are very large semi-aquatic mammals, and their barrel-shaped bodies have <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/graviportal" title="wikt:graviportal">graviportal</a> skeletal structures,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> adapted to carrying their enormous weight, and their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Specific_gravity" title="Specific gravity">specific gravity</a> allows them to sink and move along the bottom of a river.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Behavior">Behavior</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Communication_and_vocalization">Communication and vocalization</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Animal_communication" title="Animal communication">Animal communication</a> and <a href="/wiki/Animal_echolocation" title="Animal echolocation">Animal echolocation</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="2348" decoding="async" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG/170px-Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG/255px-Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG/340px-Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vervet_monkey" title="Vervet monkey">Vervet monkeys</a> use at least four distinct <a href="/wiki/Alarm_signal" title="Alarm signal">alarm calls</a> for different <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Predator" title="Predator">predators</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Seyfarth_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-Seyfarth-171">[171]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Many mammals communicate by vocalizing. Vocal communication serves many purposes, including in mating rituals, as <a href="/wiki/Alarm_signal" title="Alarm signal">warning calls</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> to indicate food sources, and for social purposes. Males often call during mating rituals to ward off other males and to attract females, as in the <a href="/wiki/Roar_(vocalization)" title="Roar (vocalization)">roaring</a> of <a href="/wiki/Lion" title="Lion">lions</a> and <a href="/wiki/Red_deer" title="Red deer">red deer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Whale_song" title="Whale song">songs</a> of the humpback whale may be signals to females;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> they have different dialects in different regions of the ocean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> Social vocalizations include the <a href="/wiki/Territory_(animal)" title="Territory (animal)">territorial</a> calls of <a href="/wiki/Gibbon" title="Gibbon">gibbons</a>, and the use of frequency in <a href="/wiki/Greater_spear-nosed_bat" title="Greater spear-nosed bat">greater spear-nosed bats</a> to distinguish between groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Vervet_monkey" title="Vervet monkey">vervet monkey</a> gives a distinct alarm call for each of at least four different predators, and the reactions of other monkeys vary according to the call. For example, if an alarm call signals a python, the monkeys climb into the trees, whereas the eagle alarm causes monkeys to seek a hiding place on the ground.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Seyfarth_171-1"><a href="#cite_note-Seyfarth-171">[171]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prairie_dogs" title="Prairie dogs">Prairie dogs</a> similarly have complex calls that signal the type, size, and speed of an approaching predator.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> Elephants communicate socially with a variety of sounds including snorting, screaming, trumpeting, roaring and rumbling. Some of the rumbling calls are <a href="/wiki/Infrasound" title="Infrasound">infrasonic</a>, below the hearing range of humans, and can be heard by other elephants up to 6 miles (9.7 km) away at still times near sunrise and sunset.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><audio class="thumbimage" controls="" data-durationhint="30" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Killer_whale.ogg" id="mwe_player_3" preload="none" style="width:220px;" width="220"><source data-bandwidth="73562" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (74 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/79/Killer_whale.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="118576" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/79/Killer_whale.ogg/Killer_whale.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/></audio> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Killer_whale.ogg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Orca calling including occasional echolocation clicks</div></div></div>
<p>Mammals signal by a variety of means. Many give visual <a href="/wiki/Anti-predator_adaptation" title="Anti-predator adaptation">anti-predator signals</a>, as when deer and <a href="/wiki/Gazelle" title="Gazelle">gazelle</a> <a href="/wiki/Stotting" title="Stotting">stot</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Honest_signal" title="Honest signal">honestly indicating</a> their fit condition and their ability to escape,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> or when <a href="/wiki/White-tailed_deer" title="White-tailed deer">white-tailed deer</a> and other prey mammals flag with conspicuous tail markings when alarmed, informing the predator that it has been detected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> Many mammals make use of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scent-marking" title="Scent-marking">scent-marking</a>, sometimes possibly to help defend territory, but probably with a range of functions both within and between species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Microbat" title="Microbat">Microbats</a> and <a href="/wiki/Toothed_whale" title="Toothed whale">toothed whales</a> including <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_dolphin" title="Oceanic dolphin">oceanic dolphins</a> vocalize both socially and in <a href="/wiki/Animal_echolocation" title="Animal echolocation">echolocation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Feeding">Feeding</span></h3>
