codecs="vp9, opus"'/><source data-bandwidth="520904" data-framerate="0" data-height="360" data-shorttitle="WebM 360P" data-title="WebM (360P)" data-transcodekey="360p.webm" data-width="640" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.360p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="639800" data-framerate="0" data-height="360" data-shorttitle="VP9 360P" data-title="VP9 (360P)" data-transcodekey="360p.vp9.webm" data-width="640" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.360p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"'/></video> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Short-beaked_echidna" title="Short-beaked echidna">short-beaked echidna</a> foraging for insects.</div></div></div>
<p>To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive—mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species have since adapted to meet their dietary requirements in a variety of ways. Some eat other animals—this is a <a href="/wiki/Carnivore" title="Carnivore">carnivorous</a> diet (and includes insectivorous diets). Other mammals, called <a href="/wiki/Herbivore" title="Herbivore">herbivores</a>, eat plants, which contain <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Complex_carbohydrate" title="Complex carbohydrate">complex carbohydrates</a> such as cellulose. An herbivorous diet includes subtypes such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Granivory" title="Granivory">granivory</a> (seed eating), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folivory" title="Folivory">folivory</a> (leaf eating), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Frugivory" title="Frugivory">frugivory</a> (fruit eating), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nectarivory" title="Nectarivory">nectarivory</a> (nectar eating), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gummivory" title="Gummivory">gummivory</a> (gum eating) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mycophagy" title="Mycophagy">mycophagy</a> (fungus eating). The digestive tract of an herbivore is host to bacteria that ferment these complex substances, and make them available for digestion, which are either housed in the multichambered <a href="/wiki/Stomach" title="Stomach">stomach</a> or in a large cecum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Comparative_anatomy_of_the_stomach_91-1"><a href="#cite_note-Comparative_anatomy_of_the_stomach-91">[91]</a></sup> Some mammals are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coprophagous" title="Coprophagous">coprophagous</a>, consuming <a href="/wiki/Feces" title="Feces">feces</a> to absorb the nutrients not digested when the food was first ingested.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-8"><a href="#cite_note-hair-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 131–137">: 131–137 </span></sup> An <a href="/wiki/Omnivore" title="Omnivore">omnivore</a> eats both prey and plants. Carnivorous mammals have a simple <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Digestive_system" title="Digestive system">digestive tract</a> because the <a href="/wiki/Protein" title="Protein">proteins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lipid" title="Lipid">lipids</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mineral" title="Mineral">minerals</a> found in meat require little in the way of specialized digestion. Exceptions to this include <a href="/wiki/Baleen_whale" title="Baleen whale">baleen whales</a> who also house <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gut_flora" title="Gut flora">gut flora</a> in a multi-chambered stomach, like terrestrial herbivores.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup>
</p><p>The size of an animal is also a factor in determining diet type (<a href="/wiki/Allen%27s_rule" title="Allen's rule">Allen's rule</a>). Since small mammals have a high ratio of heat-losing surface area to heat-generating volume, they tend to have high energy requirements and a high <a href="/wiki/Metabolism" title="Metabolism">metabolic rate</a>. Mammals that weigh less than about 18 ounces (510 g; 1.1 lb) are mostly insectivorous because they cannot tolerate the slow, complex digestive process of an herbivore. Larger animals, on the other hand, generate more heat and less of this heat is lost. They can therefore tolerate either a slower collection process (carnivores that feed on larger vertebrates) or a slower digestive process (herbivores).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> Furthermore, mammals that weigh more than 18 ounces (510 g; 1.1 lb) usually cannot collect enough insects during their waking hours to sustain themselves. The only large insectivorous mammals are those that feed on huge colonies of insects (<a href="/wiki/Ant" title="Ant">ants</a> or <a href="/wiki/Termite" title="Termite">termites</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Smithsonian_Animal_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-Smithsonian_Animal-190">[190]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Blacky.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1512" data-file-width="2016" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Blacky.jpg/200px-Blacky.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Blacky.jpg/300px-Blacky.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Blacky.jpg/400px-Blacky.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_polar_bear_(Ursus_maritimus)_scavenging_a_narwhal_whale_(Monodon_monoceros)_carcass_-_journal.pone.0060797.g001-A.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="578" data-file-width="1170" decoding="async" height="99" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/A_polar_bear_%28Ursus_maritimus%29_scavenging_a_narwhal_whale_%28Monodon_monoceros%29_carcass_-_journal.pone.0060797.g001-A.png/200px-A_polar_bear_%28Ursus_maritimus%29_scavenging_a_narwhal_whale_%28Monodon_monoceros%29_carcass_-_journal.pone.0060797.g001-A.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/A_polar_bear_%28Ursus_maritimus%29_scavenging_a_narwhal_whale_%28Monodon_monoceros%29_carcass_-_journal.pone.0060797.g001-A.png/300px-A_polar_bear_%28Ursus_maritimus%29_scavenging_a_narwhal_whale_%28Monodon_monoceros%29_carcass_-_journal.pone.0060797.g001-A.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/A_polar_bear_%28Ursus_maritimus%29_scavenging_a_narwhal_whale_%28Monodon_monoceros%29_carcass_-_journal.pone.0060797.g001-A.png/400px-A_polar_bear_%28Ursus_maritimus%29_scavenging_a_narwhal_whale_%28Monodon_monoceros%29_carcass_-_journal.pone.0060797.g001-A.png 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Hypocarnivore" title="Hypocarnivore">hypocarnivorous</a> <a href="/wiki/American_black_bear" title="American black bear">American black bear</a> (<i>Ursus americanus</i>) vs. the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hypercarnivorous" title="Hypercarnivorous">hypercarnivorous</a> <a href="/wiki/Polar_bear" title="Polar bear">polar bear</a> (<i>Ursus maritimus</i>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-valkenburgh2007_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-valkenburgh2007-191">[191]</a></sup></div></div></div></div>
<p>Some mammals are omnivores and display varying degrees of carnivory and herbivory, generally leaning in favor of one more than the other. Since plants and meat are digested differently, there is a preference for one over the other, as in bears where some species may be mostly carnivorous and others mostly herbivorous.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> They are grouped into three categories: <a href="/wiki/Mesocarnivore" title="Mesocarnivore">mesocarnivory</a> (50–70% meat), <a href="/wiki/Hypercarnivore" title="Hypercarnivore">hypercarnivory</a> (70% and greater of meat), and <a href="/wiki/Hypocarnivore" title="Hypocarnivore">hypocarnivory</a> (50% or less of meat). The dentition of hypocarnivores consists of dull, triangular carnassial teeth meant for grinding food. Hypercarnivores, however, have conical teeth and sharp carnassials meant for slashing, and in some cases strong jaws for bone-crushing, as in the case of <a href="/wiki/Hyena" title="Hyena">hyenas</a>, allowing them to consume bones; some extinct groups, notably the <a href="/wiki/Machairodontinae" title="Machairodontinae">Machairodontinae</a>, had saber-shaped <a href="/wiki/Maxillary_canine" title="Maxillary canine">canines</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-valkenburgh2007_191-1"><a href="#cite_note-valkenburgh2007-191">[191]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some physiological carnivores consume plant matter and some physiological herbivores consume meat. From a behavioral aspect, this would make them omnivores, but from the physiological standpoint, this may be due to <a href="/wiki/Zoopharmacognosy" title="Zoopharmacognosy">zoopharmacognosy</a>. Physiologically, animals must be able to obtain both energy and nutrients from plant and animal materials to be considered omnivorous. Thus, such animals are still able to be classified as carnivores and herbivores when they are just obtaining nutrients from materials originating from sources that do not seemingly complement their classification.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> For example, it is well documented that some ungulates such as giraffes, camels, and cattle, will gnaw on bones to consume particular minerals and nutrients.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> Also, cats, which are generally regarded as obligate carnivores, occasionally eat grass to regurgitate indigestible material (such as <a href="/wiki/Hairball" title="Hairball">hairballs</a>), aid with hemoglobin production, and as a laxative.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many mammals, in the absence of sufficient food requirements in an environment, suppress their metabolism and conserve energy in a process known as <a href="/wiki/Hibernation" title="Hibernation">hibernation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> In the period preceding hibernation, larger mammals, such as bears, become <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polyphagic" title="Polyphagic">polyphagic</a> to increase fat stores, whereas smaller mammals prefer to collect and stash food.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> The slowing of the metabolism is accompanied by a decreased heart and respiratory rate, as well as a drop in internal temperatures, which can be around ambient temperature in some cases. For example, the internal temperatures of hibernating <a href="/wiki/Arctic_ground_squirrel" title="Arctic ground squirrel">arctic ground squirrels</a> can drop to −2.9 °C (26.8 °F), however the head and neck always stay above 0 °C (32 °F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> A few mammals in hot environments <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aestivate" title="Aestivate">aestivate</a> in times of drought or extreme heat, for example the <a href="/wiki/Fat-tailed_dwarf_lemur" title="Fat-tailed dwarf lemur">fat-tailed dwarf lemur</a> (<i>Cheirogaleus medius</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Intelligence">Intelligence</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Animal_cognition" title="Animal cognition">Animal cognition</a></div>
<p>In intelligent mammals, such as <a href="/wiki/Primate" title="Primate">primates</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Cerebrum" title="Cerebrum">cerebrum</a> is larger relative to the rest of the brain. <a href="/wiki/Intelligence" title="Intelligence">Intelligence</a> itself is not easy to define, but indications of intelligence include the ability to learn, matched with behavioral flexibility. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rat_IQ" title="Rat IQ">Rats</a>, for example, are considered to be highly intelligent, as they can learn and perform new tasks, an ability that may be important when they first colonize a fresh <a href="/wiki/Biome" title="Biome">habitat</a>. In some mammals, food gathering appears to be related to intelligence: a deer feeding on plants has a brain smaller than a cat, which must think to outwit its prey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Smithsonian_Animal_190-1"><a href="#cite_note-Smithsonian_Animal-190">[190]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1952" data-file-width="2608" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg/220px-A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg/330px-A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg/440px-A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Bonobo" title="Bonobo">bonobo</a> fishing for <a href="/wiki/Termite" title="Termite">termites</a> with a stick</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tool_use_by_animals" title="Tool use by animals">Tool use by animals</a> may indicate different levels of <a href="/wiki/Learning" title="Learning">learning</a> and <a href="/wiki/Animal_cognition" title="Animal cognition">cognition</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Tool_use_by_sea_otters" title="Tool use by sea otters">sea otter</a> uses rocks as essential and regular parts of its foraging behaviour (smashing <a href="/wiki/Abalone" title="Abalone">abalone</a> from rocks or breaking open shells), with some populations spending 21% of their time making tools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> Other tool use, such as <a href="/wiki/Chimpanzee" title="Chimpanzee">chimpanzees</a> using twigs to "fish" for termites, may be developed by <a href="/wiki/Observational_learning" title="Observational learning">watching others use tools</a> and may even be a true example of animal teaching.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> Tools may even be used in solving puzzles in which the animal appears to experience a <a href="/wiki/Eureka_effect" title="Eureka effect">"Eureka moment"</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> Other mammals that do not use tools, such as dogs, can also experience a Eureka moment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Brain_size" title="Brain size">Brain size</a> was previously considered a major indicator of the intelligence of an animal. Since most of the brain is used for maintaining bodily functions, greater ratios of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brain-to-body_mass_ratio" title="Brain-to-body mass ratio">brain to body mass</a> may increase the amount of brain mass available for more complex cognitive tasks. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Allometric" title="Allometric">Allometric</a> analysis indicates that mammalian brain size scales at approximately the <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style><span class="frac" role="math"><span class="num">2</span>⁄<span class="den">3</span></span> or <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1020198016" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="frac" role="math"><span class="num">3</span>⁄<span class="den">4</span></span> exponent of the body mass. Comparison of a particular animal's brain size with the expected brain size based on such allometric analysis provides an <a href="/wiki/Encephalization_quotient" title="Encephalization quotient">encephalisation quotient</a> that can be used as another indication of animal intelligence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sperm_whale" title="Sperm whale">Sperm whales</a> have the largest brain mass of any animal on earth, averaging 8,000 cubic centimetres (490 in<sup>3</sup>) and 7.8 kilograms (17 lb) in mature males.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Self-awareness" title="Self-awareness">Self-awareness</a> appears to be a sign of abstract thinking. Self-awareness, although not well-defined, is believed to be a precursor to more advanced processes such as <a href="/wiki/Metacognition" title="Metacognition">metacognitive reasoning</a>. The traditional method for measuring this is the <a href="/wiki/Mirror_test" title="Mirror test">mirror test</a>, which determines if an animal possesses the ability of self-recognition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> Mammals that have passed the mirror test include Asian elephants (some pass, some do not);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> chimpanzees;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-robert_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-robert-208">[208]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bonobo" title="Bonobo">bonobos</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Orangutan" title="Orangutan">orangutans</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-orangutan_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-orangutan-210">[210]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Human" title="Human">humans</a>, from 18 months (<a href="/wiki/Mirror_stage" title="Mirror stage">mirror stage</a>);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archer_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-archer-211">[211]</a></sup> bottlenose dolphins<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[a]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parker95_212-1"><a href="#cite_note-parker95-212">[212]</a></sup> killer whales;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Delfour_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-Delfour-214">[213]</a></sup> and false killer whales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Delfour_214-1"><a href="#cite_note-Delfour-214">[213]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_structure">Social structure</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_animal" title="Social animal">Social animal</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Borneo_elephants.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="650" data-file-width="650" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Borneo_elephants.png/220px-Borneo_elephants.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Borneo_elephants.png/330px-Borneo_elephants.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Borneo_elephants.png/440px-Borneo_elephants.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Borneo_elephants.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Female elephants live in stable groups, along with their offspring.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Eusociality" title="Eusociality">Eusociality</a> is the highest level of social organization. These societies have an overlap of adult generations, the division of reproductive labor and cooperative caring of young. Usually insects, such as <a href="/wiki/Bee" title="Bee">bees</a>, ants and termites, have eusocial behavior, but it is demonstrated in two rodent species: the naked mole-rat<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[214]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Damaraland_mole-rat" title="Damaraland mole-rat">Damaraland mole-rat</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[215]</a></sup>
</p><p>Presociality is when animals exhibit more than just sexual interactions with members of the same species, but fall short of qualifying as eusocial. That is, presocial animals can display communal living, cooperative care of young, or primitive division of reproductive labor, but they do not display all of the three essential traits of eusocial animals. Humans and some species of <a href="/wiki/Callitrichidae" title="Callitrichidae">Callitrichidae</a> (<a href="/wiki/Marmoset" title="Marmoset">marmosets</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tamarin" title="Tamarin">tamarins</a>) are unique among primates in their degree of cooperative care of young.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[216]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Harry_Harlow" title="Harry Harlow">Harry Harlow</a> set up an experiment with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rhesus_monkey" title="Rhesus monkey">rhesus monkeys</a>, presocial primates, in 1958; the results from this study showed that social encounters are necessary in order for the young monkeys to develop both mentally and sexually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harlow71_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-Harlow71-218">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fission-fusion_society" title="Fission-fusion society">fission-fusion society</a> is a society that changes frequently in its size and composition, making up a permanent social group called the "parent group". Permanent social networks consist of all individual members of a community and often varies to track changes in their environment. In a fission–fusion society, the main parent group can fracture (fission) into smaller stable subgroups or individuals to adapt to <a href="/wiki/Social_environment" title="Social environment">environmental</a> or social circumstances. For example, a number of males may break off from the main group in order to hunt or forage for food during the day, but at night they may return to join (fusion) the primary group to share food and partake in other activities. Many mammals exhibit this, such as primates (for example orangutans and <a href="/wiki/Spider_monkey" title="Spider monkey">spider monkeys</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[218]</a></sup> elephants,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[219]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Spotted_hyena" title="Spotted hyena">spotted hyenas</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[220]</a></sup> lions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[221]</a></sup> and dolphins.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[222]</a></sup>
</p><p>Solitary animals defend a territory and avoid social interactions with the members of its species, except during breeding season. This is to avoid resource competition, as two individuals of the same species would occupy the same niche, and to prevent depletion of food.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[223]</a></sup> A solitary animal, while foraging, can also be less conspicuous to predators or prey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[224]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1710" data-file-width="2250" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg/220px-Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg/330px-Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg/440px-Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Red_kangaroo" title="Red kangaroo">Red kangaroos</a> "boxing" for <a href="/wiki/Dominance_hierarchy" title="Dominance hierarchy">dominance</a></div></div></div>
<p>In a <a href="/wiki/Dominance_hierarchy" title="Dominance hierarchy">hierarchy</a>, individuals are either dominant or submissive. A despotic hierarchy is where one individual is dominant while the others are submissive, as in wolves and lemurs,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[225]</a></sup> and a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pecking_order" title="Pecking order">pecking order</a> is a linear ranking of individuals where there is a top individual and a bottom individual. Pecking orders may also be ranked by sex, where the lowest individual of a sex has a higher ranking than the top individual of the other sex, as in hyenas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[226]</a></sup> Dominant individuals, or alphas, have a high chance of reproductive success, especially in <a href="/wiki/Harem_(zoology)" title="Harem (zoology)">harems</a> where one or a few males (resident males) have exclusive breeding rights to females in a group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[227]</a></sup> Non-resident males can also be accepted in harems, but some species, such as the <a href="/wiki/Common_vampire_bat" title="Common vampire bat">common vampire bat</a> (<i>Desmodus rotundus</i>), may be more strict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[228]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some mammals are perfectly <a href="/wiki/Monogamy_in_animals" title="Monogamy in animals">monogamous</a>, meaning that they <a href="/wiki/Pair_bond" title="Pair bond">mate for life</a> and take no other partners (even after the original mate's death), as with wolves, <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_beaver" title="Eurasian beaver">Eurasian beavers</a>, and otters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[230]</a></sup> There are three types of polygamy: either one or multiple dominant males have breeding rights (<a href="/wiki/Polygyny_in_animals" title="Polygyny in animals">polygyny</a>), multiple males that females mate with (polyandry), or multiple males have exclusive relations with multiple females (<a href="/wiki/Polygynandry" title="Polygynandry">polygynandry</a>). It is much more common for polygynous mating to happen, which, excluding <a href="/wiki/Lek_mating" title="Lek mating">leks</a>, are estimated to occur in up to 90% of mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[231]</a></sup> Lek mating occurs when males congregate around females and try to attract them with various <a href="/wiki/Courtship_display" title="Courtship display">courtship displays</a> and vocalizations, as in harbor seals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[232]</a></sup>
</p><p>All <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Higher_mammal" title="Higher mammal">higher mammals</a> (excluding monotremes) share two major adaptations for care of the young: live birth and lactation. These imply a group-wide choice of a degree of <a href="/wiki/Parental_care" title="Parental care">parental care</a>. They may build nests and dig burrows to raise their young in, or feed and guard them often for a prolonged period of time. Many mammals are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/K-selected" title="K-selected">K-selected</a>, and invest more time and energy into their young than do <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/R-selected" title="R-selected">r-selected</a> animals. When two animals mate, they both share an interest in the success of the offspring, though often to different extremes. Mammalian females exhibit some degree of maternal aggression, another example of parental care, which may be targeted against other females of the species or the young of other females; however, some mammals may "aunt" the infants of other females, and care for them. Mammalian males may play a role in child rearing, as with tenrecs, however this varies species to species, even within the same genus. For example, the males of the <a href="/wiki/Southern_pig-tailed_macaque" title="Southern pig-tailed macaque">southern pig-tailed macaque</a> (<i>Macaca nemestrina</i>) do not participate in child care, whereas the males of the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_macaque" title="Japanese macaque">Japanese macaque</a> (<i>M. fuscata</i>) do.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[233]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Humans_and_other_mammals">Humans and other mammals</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_uses_of_mammals" title="Human uses of mammals">Human uses of mammals</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="In_human_culture">In human culture</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lascaux_painting.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="472" data-file-width="720" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Lascaux_painting.jpg/220px-Lascaux_painting.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Lascaux_painting.jpg/330px-Lascaux_painting.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Lascaux_painting.jpg/440px-Lascaux_painting.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lascaux_painting.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic" title="Upper Paleolithic">Upper Paleolithic</a> <a href="/wiki/Cave_painting" title="Cave painting">cave painting</a> of a variety of large mammals, <a href="/wiki/Lascaux" title="Lascaux">Lascaux</a>, c. 17,300 years old</div></div></div>
<p>Non-human mammals play a wide variety of roles in human culture. They are the most popular of <a href="/wiki/Pet" title="Pet">pets</a>, with tens of millions of dogs, cats and other animals including <a href="/wiki/Rabbit" title="Rabbit">rabbits</a> and mice kept by families around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[234]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[236]</a></sup> Mammals such as <a href="/wiki/Mammoth" title="Mammoth">mammoths</a>, horses and deer are among the earliest subjects of art, being found in <a href="/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic" title="Upper Paleolithic">Upper Paleolithic</a> <a href="/wiki/Cave_painting" title="Cave painting">cave paintings</a> such as at <a href="/wiki/Lascaux" title="Lascaux">Lascaux</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[237]</a></sup> Major artists such as <a href="/wiki/Albrecht_D%C3%BCrer" title="Albrecht Dürer">Albrecht Dürer</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Stubbs" title="George Stubbs">George Stubbs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Edwin_Landseer" title="Edwin Landseer">Edwin Landseer</a> are known for their portraits of mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jones_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jones-239">[238]</a></sup> Many species of mammals have been <a href="/wiki/Hunting" title="Hunting">hunted</a> for sport and for food; deer and <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">wild boar</a> are especially popular as <a href="/wiki/Game_(hunting)" title="Game (hunting)">game animals</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[241]</a></sup> Mammals such as <a href="/wiki/Horse_racing" title="Horse racing">horses</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greyhound_racing" title="Greyhound racing">dogs</a> are widely raced for sport, often combined with <a href="/wiki/Gambling" title="Gambling">betting on the outcome</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[243]</a></sup> There is a tension between the role of animals as companions to humans, and their existence as individuals with <a href="/wiki/Animal_rights" title="Animal rights">rights of their own</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[244]</a></sup> Mammals further play a wide variety of roles in literature,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[245]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[246]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[247]</a></sup> film,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[248]</a></sup> mythology, and religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[250]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[251]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Uses_and_importance">Uses and importance</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Livestock" title="Livestock">Livestock</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Laboratory_animal" title="Laboratory animal">Laboratory animal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pack_animal" title="Pack animal">Pack animal</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg/170px-Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg/255px-Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg/340px-Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Cattle" title="Cattle">Cattle</a> have been <a href="/wiki/Dairy_farming" title="Dairy farming">kept for milk</a> for thousands of years.</div></div></div>
<p>The domestication of mammals was instrumental in the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic_Revolution" title="Neolithic Revolution">Neolithic development of agriculture</a> and of <a href="/wiki/Civilization" title="Civilization">civilization</a>, causing farmers to replace <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherers</a> around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[b]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Larson_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-Larson-255">[253]</a></sup> This transition from hunting and gathering to <a href="/wiki/Pastoralism" title="Pastoralism">herding flocks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">growing crops</a> was a major step in human history. The new agricultural economies, based on domesticated mammals, caused "radical restructuring of human societies, worldwide alterations in biodiversity, and significant changes in the Earth's landforms and its atmosphere... momentous outcomes".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[254]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Domestication" title="Domestication">Domestic</a> mammals form a large part of the <a href="/wiki/Livestock" title="Livestock">livestock</a> raised for <a href="/wiki/Meat" title="Meat">meat</a> across the world. They include (2009) around 1.4 billion <a href="/wiki/Cattle" title="Cattle">cattle</a>, 1 billion <a href="/wiki/Sheep" title="Sheep">sheep</a>, 1 billion <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Domestic_pig" title="Domestic pig">domestic pigs</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[256]</a></sup> and (1985) over 700 million rabbits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[257]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Working_animal" title="Working animal">Working domestic animals</a> including cattle and horses have been used for work and <a href="/wiki/Transport" title="Transport">transport</a> from the origins of agriculture, their numbers declining with the arrival of mechanised transport and <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_machinery" title="Agricultural machinery">agricultural machinery</a>. In 2004 they still provided some 80% of the power for the mainly small farms in the third world, and some 20% of the world's transport, again mainly in rural areas. In mountainous regions unsuitable for wheeled vehicles, <a href="/wiki/Pack_animal" title="Pack animal">pack animals</a> continue to transport goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pond2004_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pond2004-260">[258]</a></sup> Mammal skins provide <a href="/wiki/Leather" title="Leather">leather</a> for <a href="/wiki/Shoe" title="Shoe">shoes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clothing" title="Clothing">clothing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Upholstery" title="Upholstery">upholstery</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[259]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wool" title="Wool">Wool</a> from mammals including sheep, goats and <a href="/wiki/Alpaca" title="Alpaca">alpacas</a> has been used for centuries for clothing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[261]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:434px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2360" data-file-width="2454" decoding="async" height="415" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png/432px-Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png/648px-Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png/864px-Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png 2x" width="432"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Wild mammals make up only 4% of all mammals, while humans and their livestock represent 96% of all mammals in terms of biomass.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bar-On_2018_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bar-On_2018-264">[262]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Mammals serve a major role in science as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Animal_model" title="Animal model">experimental animals</a>, both in fundamental biological research, such as in genetics,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[263]</a></sup> and in the development of new medicines, which must be tested exhaustively to demonstrate their <a href="/wiki/Pharmacovigilance" title="Pharmacovigilance">safety</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[264]</a></sup> Millions of mammals, especially mice and rats, are used in <a href="/wiki/Animal_testing" title="Animal testing">experiments</a> each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EUstatistics2013_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-EUstatistics2013-267">[265]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Knockout_mouse" title="Knockout mouse">knockout mouse</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Genetically_modified_mouse" title="Genetically modified mouse">genetically modified mouse</a> with an inactivated <a href="/wiki/Gene" title="Gene">gene</a>, replaced or disrupted with an artificial piece of DNA. They enable the study of <a href="/wiki/Sequencing" title="Sequencing">sequenced</a> genes whose functions are unknown.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[266]</a></sup> A small percentage of the mammals are non-human primates, used in research for their similarity to humans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[267]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carlsson2004_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-Carlsson2004-270">[268]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Weatherall_etal2006_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-Weatherall_etal2006-271">[269]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite the benefits domesticated mammals had for human development, humans have an increasingly detrimental effect on wild mammals across the world. It has been estimated that the mass of all <i>wild</i> mammals has declined to only 4% of all mammals, with 96% of mammals being humans and their livestock now (see figure). In fact, terrestrial wild mammals make up only 2% of all mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bar-On_2018_264-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bar-On_2018-264">[262]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hybrids">Hybrids</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_(biology)" title="Hybrid (biology)">Hybrid (biology)</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Equus_quagga_quagga,_coloured.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="798" data-file-width="1138" decoding="async" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Equus_quagga_quagga%2C_coloured.jpg/200px-Equus_quagga_quagga%2C_coloured.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Equus_quagga_quagga%2C_coloured.jpg/300px-Equus_quagga_quagga%2C_coloured.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Equus_quagga_quagga%2C_coloured.jpg/400px-Equus_quagga_quagga%2C_coloured.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="904" data-file-width="1400" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg/200px-Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg/300px-Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg/400px-Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">A true <a href="/wiki/Quagga" title="Quagga">quagga</a>, 1870 (left) vs. a <a href="/wiki/Quagga_Project" title="Quagga Project">bred-back quagga</a>, 2014 (right)</div></div></div></div>
<p>Hybrids are offspring resulting from the breeding of two genetically distinct individuals, which usually will result in a high degree of heterozygosity, though hybrid and heterozygous are not synonymous. The deliberate or accidental hybridizing of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown for economic purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[271]</a></sup> Hybrids between different subspecies within a species (such as between the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_tiger" title="Bengal tiger">Bengal tiger</a> and <a href="/wiki/Siberian_tiger" title="Siberian tiger">Siberian tiger</a>) are known as intra-specific hybrids. Hybrids between different species within the same genus (such as between lions and tigers) are known as interspecific hybrids or crosses. Hybrids between different genera (such as between sheep and goats) are known as intergeneric hybrids.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[272]</a></sup> Natural hybrids will occur in <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_zone" title="Hybrid zone">hybrid zones</a>, where two populations of species within the same genera or species living in the same or adjacent areas will interbreed with each other. Some hybrids have been recognized as species, such as the <a href="/wiki/Red_wolf" title="Red wolf">red wolf</a> (though this is controversial).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[273]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Artificial_selection" title="Artificial selection">Artificial selection</a>, the deliberate <a href="/wiki/Selective_breeding" title="Selective breeding">selective breeding</a> of domestic animals, is being used to <a href="/wiki/Breeding_back" title="Breeding back">breed back</a> <a href="/wiki/Holocene_extinction" title="Holocene extinction">recently extinct</a> animals in an attempt to achieve an animal breed with a <a href="/wiki/Phenotype" title="Phenotype">phenotype</a> that resembles that extinct <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wildtype" title="Wildtype">wildtype</a> ancestor. A breeding-back (intraspecific) hybrid may be very similar to the extinct wildtype in appearance, ecological niche and to some extent genetics, but the initial <a href="/wiki/Gene_pool" title="Gene pool">gene pool</a> of that wild type is lost forever with its <a href="/wiki/Extinction" title="Extinction">extinction</a>. As a result, bred-back breeds are at best vague look-alikes of extinct wildtypes, as <a href="/wiki/Heck_cattle" title="Heck cattle">Heck cattle</a> are of the <a href="/wiki/Aurochs" title="Aurochs">aurochs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vanVuure_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-vanVuure-276">[274]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Purebred" title="Purebred">Purebred</a> wild species evolved to a specific ecology can be threatened with extinction<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[275]</a></sup> through the process of <a href="/wiki/Genetic_pollution" title="Genetic pollution">genetic pollution</a>, the uncontrolled hybridization, <a href="/wiki/Introgression" title="Introgression">introgression</a> genetic swamping which leads to homogenization or <a href="/wiki/Fitness_(biology)" title="Fitness (biology)">out-competition</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Heterosis" title="Heterosis">heterosic</a> hybrid species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[276]</a></sup> When new populations are imported or selectively bred by people, or when habitat modification brings previously isolated species into contact, extinction in some species, especially rare varieties, is possible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[277]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Interbreeding" title="Interbreeding">Interbreeding</a> can swamp the rarer gene pool and create hybrids, depleting the purebred gene pool. For example, the endangered <a href="/wiki/Wild_water_buffalo" title="Wild water buffalo">wild water buffalo</a> is most threatened with extinction by genetic pollution from the <a href="/wiki/Water_buffalo" title="Water buffalo">domestic water buffalo</a>. Such extinctions are not always apparent from a <a href="/wiki/Morphology_(biology)" title="Morphology (biology)">morphological</a> standpoint. Some degree of <a href="/wiki/Gene_flow" title="Gene flow">gene flow</a> is a normal evolutionary process, nevertheless, hybridization threatens the existence of rare species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[278]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[279]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Threats">Threats</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Holocene_extinction" title="Holocene extinction">Holocene extinction</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Extinctions_Africa_Austrailia_NAmerica_Madagascar.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="452" data-file-width="441" decoding="async" height="318" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Extinctions_Africa_Austrailia_NAmerica_Madagascar.gif/310px-Extinctions_Africa_Austrailia_NAmerica_Madagascar.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/ad/Extinctions_Africa_Austrailia_NAmerica_Madagascar.gif 1.5x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Extinctions_Africa_Austrailia_NAmerica_Madagascar.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Biodiversity of large mammal species per continent before and after humans arrived there</div></div></div>
<p>The loss of species from ecological communities, <a href="/wiki/Defaunation" title="Defaunation">defaunation</a>, is primarily driven by human activity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dirzo_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-dirzo-282">[280]</a></sup> This has resulted in <a href="/wiki/Empty_forest" title="Empty forest">empty forests</a>, ecological communities depleted of large vertebrates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-primack2014_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-primack2014-283">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[282]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Quaternary_extinction_event" title="Quaternary extinction event">Quaternary extinction event</a>, the mass die-off of <a href="/wiki/Megafauna" title="Megafauna">megafaunal</a> variety coincided with the appearance of humans, suggesting a human influence. One hypothesis is that humans hunted large mammals, such as the <a href="/wiki/Woolly_mammoth" title="Woolly mammoth">woolly mammoth</a>, into extinction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[284]</a></sup> The 2019 <i><a href="/wiki/Global_Assessment_Report_on_Biodiversity_and_Ecosystem_Services" title="Global Assessment Report on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services">Global Assessment Report on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services</a></i> by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IPBES" title="IPBES">IPBES</a> states that the total <a href="/wiki/Biomass_(ecology)" title="Biomass (ecology)">biomass</a> of wild mammals has declined by 82 percent since the beginning of human civilization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[286]</a></sup> Wild animals make up just 4% of mammalian <a href="/wiki/Biomass_(ecology)" title="Biomass (ecology)">biomass</a> on earth, while humans and their domesticated animals make up 96%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bar-On_2018_264-2"><a href="#cite_note-Bar-On_2018-264">[262]</a></sup>
</p><p>Various species are predicted to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_critically_endangered_species" title="List of critically endangered species">become extinct in the near future</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[287]</a></sup> among them the <a href="/wiki/Rhinoceros" title="Rhinoceros">rhinoceros</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[288]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Giraffes" title="Giraffes">giraffes</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[289]</a></sup> and species of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Primates" title="Primates">primates</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-primates_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-primates-292">[290]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pangolins" title="Pangolins">pangolins</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[291]</a></sup> According to the WWF's 2020 <i><a href="/wiki/Living_Planet_Report" title="Living Planet Report">Living Planet Report</a></i>, vertebrate <a href="/wiki/Wildlife" title="Wildlife">wildlife</a> populations have declined by 68% since 1970 as a result of human activities, particularly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Overconsumption" title="Overconsumption">overconsumption</a>, <a href="/wiki/Population_growth" title="Population growth">population growth</a> and <a href="/wiki/Intensive_farming" title="Intensive farming">intensive farming</a>, which is evidence that humans have triggered a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sixth_mass_extinction" title="Sixth mass extinction">sixth mass extinction</a> event.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[292]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[293]</a></sup> Hunting alone threatens hundreds of mammalian species around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[294]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[295]</a></sup> Scientists claim that the growing demand for <a href="/wiki/Meat" title="Meat">meat</a> is contributing to <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_loss" title="Biodiversity loss">biodiversity loss</a> as this is a significant driver of <a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">deforestation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Habitat_destruction" title="Habitat destruction">habitat destruction</a>; species-rich habitats, such as significant portions of the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">Amazon rainforest</a>, are being converted to agricultural land for meat production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[296]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[297]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[298]</a></sup> Another influence is over-hunting and <a href="/wiki/Species_affected_by_poaching" title="Species affected by poaching">poaching</a>, which can reduce the overall population of game animals,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[299]</a></sup> especially those located near villages,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-peres2006_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-peres2006-302">[300]</a></sup> as in the case of <a href="/wiki/Peccary" title="Peccary">peccaries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[301]</a></sup> The effects of poaching can especially be seen in the <a href="/wiki/Ivory_trade" title="Ivory trade">ivory trade</a> with African elephants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[302]</a></sup> Marine mammals are at risk from entanglement from fishing gear, notably <a href="/wiki/Cetacean_bycatch" title="Cetacean bycatch">cetaceans</a>, with discard mortalities ranging from 65,000 to 86,000 individuals annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[303]</a></sup>
</p><p>Attention is being given to endangered species globally, notably through the <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_Biological_Diversity" title="Convention on Biological Diversity">Convention on Biological Diversity</a>, otherwise known as the Rio Accord, which includes 189 signatory countries that are focused on identifying endangered species and habitats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[304]</a></sup> Another notable conservation organization is the IUCN, which has a membership of over 1,200 governmental and <a href="/wiki/Non-governmental_organization" title="Non-governmental organization">non-governmental</a> organizations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[305]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/List_of_recently_extinct_mammals" title="List of recently extinct mammals">Recent extinctions</a> can be directly attributed to human influences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ceballos_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-ceballos-308">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dirzo_282-1"><a href="#cite_note-dirzo-282">[280]</a></sup> The IUCN characterizes 'recent' extinction as those that have occurred past the cut-off point of 1500,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[307]</a></sup> and around 80 mammal species have gone extinct since that time and 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[308]</a></sup> Some species, such as the <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A8re_David%27s_deer" title="Père David's deer">Père David's deer</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[309]</a></sup> are <a href="/wiki/Extinct_in_the_wild" title="Extinct in the wild">extinct in the wild</a>, and survive solely in captive populations. Other species, such as the <a href="/wiki/Florida_panther" title="Florida panther">Florida panther</a>, are <a href="/wiki/Ecological_extinction" title="Ecological extinction">ecologically extinct</a>, surviving in such low numbers that they essentially have no impact on the ecosystem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mckinney2013_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-mckinney2013-312">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 318">: 318 </span></sup> Other populations are only <a href="/wiki/Local_extinction" title="Local extinction">locally extinct</a> (extirpated), still existing elsewhere, but reduced in distribution,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mckinney2013_312-1"><a href="#cite_note-mckinney2013-312">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 75–77">: 75–77 </span></sup> as with the extinction of <a href="/wiki/Gray_whale" title="Gray whale">gray whales</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[311]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-213"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-213">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Decreased latency to approach the mirror, repetitious head circling and close viewing of the marked areas were considered signs of self-recognition since they do not have arms and cannot touch the marked areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parker95_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-parker95-212">[212]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-254"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-254">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Diamond discussed this matter further in his 1997 book <i><a href="/wiki/Guns,_Germs,_and_Steel" title="Guns, Germs, and Steel">Guns, Germs, and Steel</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[252]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1067248974">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit;word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#3a3;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1" id="CITEREFLewisShort1879">Lewis, Charlton T.; <li id="cite_note-Simpson-1945-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Simpson-1945_3-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFSimpson1945"><a href="/wiki/George_Gaylord_Simpson" title="George Gaylord Simpson">Simpson GG</a> (1945). <li id="cite_note-Szalay-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Szalay_4-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Szalay_4-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFSzalay1999">Szalay FS (1999). "Classification of mammals above the species level: Review". <i>Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology</i>. <b>19</b> (1): 191–195. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F02724634.1999.10011133" rel="nofollow">10.1080/02724634.1999.10011133</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/4523980" rel="nofollow">4523980</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Vertebrate+Paleontology&amp;rft.atitle=Classification+of+mammals+above+the+species+level%3A+Review&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=191-195&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1080%2F02724634.1999.10011133&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F4523980%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft.aulast=Szalay&amp;rft.aufirst=FS&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMammal"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-MSW3intro-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-MSW3intro_5-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-MSW3intro_5-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFWilsonReeder2005"><a href="/wiki/Don_E._Wilson" title="Don E. Wilson">Wilson D</a>, Reeder D, eds. (2005). <a class="external text" href="http://www.departments.bucknell.edu/biology/resources/msw3/browse.asp" rel="nofollow">"Preface and introductory material"</a>. <a class="external text" href="http://www.google.com/books?id=JgAMbNSt8ikC&amp;pg=PAxxvi" rel="nofollow"><i>Mammal Species of the World: A Taxonomic and Geographic Reference</i></a> (3rd ed.). Johns Hopkins University Press. p. xxvi. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8018-8221-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8018-8221-0"><bdi>978-0-8018-8221-0</bdi></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/62265494" rel="nofollow">62265494</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Preface+and+introductory+material&amp;rft.btitle=Mammal+Species+of+the+World%3A+A+Taxonomic+and+Geographic+Reference&amp;rft.pages=xxvi&amp;rft.edition=3rd&amp;rft.pub=Johns+Hopkins+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F62265494&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8018-8221-0&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.departments.bucknell.edu%2Fbiology%2Fresources%2Fmsw3%2Fbrowse.asp&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMammal"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Scornavacca2019-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Scornavacca2019_16-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link <li id="cite_note-Kemp2006-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Kemp2006_25-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Kemp2006_25-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Kemp2006_25-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFKemp2006">Kemp TS (July 2006). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210308061139/http://users.ox.ac.uk/~tskemp/pdfs/jeb2006.pdf" rel="nofollow">"The origin and early radiation of the therapsid mammal-like reptiles: a palaeobiological hypothesis"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Journal of Evolutionary Biology</i>. <b>19</b> (4): 1231–47. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1111%2Fj.1420-9101.2005.01076.x" rel="nofollow">10.1111/j.1420-9101.2005.01076.x</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16780524" rel="nofollow">16780524</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:3184629" rel="nofollow">3184629</a>. </li>

<li id="cite_note-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-36">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHallKamilarKirk2012">Hall MI, Kamilar JM, Kirk EC (December 2012). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3497252" rel="nofollow">"Eye shape and the nocturnal bottleneck of mammals"</a>. <i>Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences</i>. <b>279</b> (1749): 4962–8. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1098%2Frspb.2012.2258" rel="nofollow">10.1098/rspb.2012.2258</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3497252" rel="nofollow">3497252</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23097513" rel="nofollow">23097513</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Proceedings+of+the+Royal+Society+B%3A+Biological+Sciences&amp;rft.atitle=Eye+shape+and+the+nocturnal+bottleneck+of+mammals&amp;rft.volume=279&amp;rft.issue=1749&amp;rft.pages=4962-8&amp;rft.date=2012-12&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC3497252%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F23097513&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1098%2Frspb.2012.2258&amp;rft.aulast=Hall&amp;rft.aufirst=MI&amp;rft.au=Kamilar%2C+JM&amp;rft.au=Kirk%2C+EC&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC3497252&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMammal"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Luo2007-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Luo2007_37-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLuo2007">Luo ZX (December 2007). <li id="cite_note-Kemp1982-48"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kemp1982_48-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKemp1982">Kemp TS (1982). <i>Mammal-like reptiles and the origin of mammals</i>. <li id="cite_note-SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates-61"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates_61-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates_61-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFSahneyBentonFerry2010">Sahney S, Benton MJ, Ferry PA (August 2010). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2936204" rel="nofollow">"Links between global taxonomic diversity, ecological diversity and the expansion of vertebrates on land"</a>. <i>Biology Letters</i>. <b>6</b> (4): 544–7. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1098%2Frsbl.2009.1024" rel="nofollow">10.1098/rsbl.2009.1024</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a <li id="cite_note-67"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-67">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHallidayUpchurchGoswami2017">Halliday TJ, Upchurch P, Goswami A (February 2017). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6849585" rel="nofollow">"Resolving the relationships of Paleocene placental mammals"</a>. <i>Biological Reviews of the Cambridge Philosophical Society</i>. <b>92</b> (1): 521–550. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1111%2Fbrv.12242" rel="nofollow">10.1111/brv.12242</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6849585" rel="nofollow">6849585</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28075073" rel="nofollow">28075073</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Biological+Reviews+of+the+Cambridge+Philosophical+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Resolving+the+relationships+of+Paleocene+placental+mammals&amp;rft.volume=92&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=521-550&amp;rft.date=2017-02&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC6849585%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F28075073&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1111%2Fbrv.12242&amp;rft.aulast=Halliday&amp;rft.aufirst=TJ&amp;rft.au=Upchurch%2C+P&amp;rft.au=Goswami%2C+A&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC6849585&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMammal"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-68"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-68">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHallidayUpchurchGoswami2016">Halliday TJ, Upchurch P, Goswami A (June 2016). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4936024" rel="nofollow">"Eutherians experienced elevated evolutionary rates in the immediate aftermath of the Cretaceous-Palaeogene mass extinction"</a>. <i>Proceedings. <li id="cite_note-77"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-77">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFCromptonJenkins_Jr1973">Crompton AW, Jenkins Jr FA (1973). "Mammals from Reptiles: A Review of Mammalian Origins". <i>Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences</i>. <b>1</b>: 131–155. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1973AREPS...1..131C" rel="nofollow">1973AREPS...1..131C</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1146%2Fannurev.ea.01.050173.001023" rel="nofollow">10.1146/annurev.ea.01.050173.001023</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Annual+Review+of+Earth+and+Planetary+Sciences&amp;rft.atitle=Mammals+from+Reptiles%3A+A+Review+of+Mammalian+Origins&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.pages=131-155&amp;rft.date=1973&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1146%2Fannurev.ea.01.050173.001023&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F1973AREPS...1..131C&amp;rft.aulast=Crompton&amp;rft.aufirst=AW&amp;rft.au=Jenkins+Jr%2C+FA&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMammal"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-schulkin-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-schulkin_78-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-schulkin_78-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFPowerSchulkin2013">Power ML, Schulkin J (2013). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=xfffGC3hjPoC&amp;pg=PA1891" rel="nofollow"><i>The Evolution Of The Human Placenta</i></a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-89"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-89">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFRomer1959">Romer AS (1959). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/vertebratestory00rome" rel="nofollow"><i>The vertebrate story</i></a></span> (4 ed.).
